content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Tyson Foods is the S&P 500’s biggest loser Monday, following an earnings report that missed expectations. Chipotle saw modest gains after analysts at Raymond James upgraded its outlook. Bloomberg Tyson TSN, +0.36%  shares skidded 9.9% to $38.44 after its earnings fell short of expectations. The company reported its second-quarter profit rose to $213 million, or 60 cents a share, from $95 million, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected earnings of 63 cents a share on revenue of $8.79 billion, according to FactSet. Also read: Tyson tells Wall Street it’s overly optimistic. Plug Power PLUG, -1.05%  fell 9.8%. About 30% of the fuel-cell suppliers shares have been sold short, according to FactSet. The company is expected to report first-quarter earnings next week. Gainers Chipotle Mexican Grill CMG, +1.13%  gained 2.3% following an upgrade to outperform from market perform by Raymond James analysts Bryan Elliott and Brian Vaccaro. The analysts said that the stock’s “recent weakness (down 20% from an all time high of $622.90 reached on March 21) creates an attractive entry point.” B/E Aerospace US:BEAV  jumped 10.3% to $98.05 a share on news it is considering a possible sale or merger. The aircraft cabin seating maker said it has retained Citigroup as its financial adviser. AAON Inc. AAON, +1.04%   rose 8.8% to $31.50 after reporting a 14.3% rise in first-quarter sales to $76.4 million. Net income rose 37.6% to $9.8 million, from $7.1 million a year ago. Engineering firm Lydall Inc. LDL, +2.01%  saw shares rise 10% to $26.02 after reporting first-quarter earnings of $125.2 million, up 26.5% from $99 million a year ago. Decliners TimeTyson Foods Inc. Cl AMay 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:TSN $60 $70 $80 Lennar Corporation LEN, +0.31%  lost 1.6% on comments made at the Ira Sohn conference by DoubleLine’s Jeffrey Gundlach that presented a dim outlook on the U.S. housing market. PulteGroup Inc. PHM, +1.41%  also fell on Gundlach’s skeptical remarks, shedding 1%. Pfizer Inc. PFE, +0.54%  dropped 2.9% to $29.86 as U.S. shareholders reacted to the company’s tepid earnings report, which saw profit shrink 15% from a year ago. J.P. Morgan JPM, +1.82%  fell 1.5% to $54.20 as it warned of a challenging trading environment. The bank also said it incurred legal expenses of $347 million in the first quarter. In addition, Norway picked Citigroup to manage its sovereign oil wealth fund, passing over J.P. Morgan. The fund is the biggest of its kind in the world, with assets of $865 billion. Bank of America BAC, +2.04%  fell 1.1% to $15.08 ahead of its shareholder meeting Wednesday. The bank revealed last week that it would be forced to scrap its plans for a dividend increase because of an accounting error that overestimated the bank’s regulatory capital by $4 billion. The California State Teachers’ Retirement System pension fund said it will vote against some board members. Target Corp. TGT, +0.36%  dropped 3.7% as Chief Executive Gregg W. Steinhafel resigned because of the continuing fallout from a holiday-season data breach that exposed sensitive data from more than 40 million customers. Also read: Target ‘sets the bar’ for credit-car security. Tickers to Watch: WFM: Whole Foods US:WFM  fell by 2.8% Monday following an analyst downgrade a day before it’s scheduled to report earnings. Wolfe Research said they were downgrading the stock from outperform to underperform. More must-reads from MarketWatch: Follow U.S. market action through the live blog 6 things you don’t know about your electric bill Warren Buffett’s company is actually a mutual fund More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Tyson Foods drops 10%; Chipotle gains on upgrade

content: ANNANDALE, Va. (MarketWatch) -- One of the noteworthy casualties of the recent bear market is a newsletter that focuses on companies involved in repurchasing their shares in the open market. But we should not count the letter out, by any means. That at least is the conclusion I drew from a recent interview with one of the finance professors who co-authored the first major study into companies involved in repurchase programs. He said that recent experience -- disappointing as it may be -- doesn't begin to cancel out the prior history in which the average buyback company significantly outperformed the market. The newsletter in question is called The Buyback Letter, edited by David Fried. Over the five years through the October 2007 stock market top, this newsletter's portfolios produced an average annualized return of 19.0%, according to the Hulbert Financial Digest. That was good enough to put the newsletter in 21st place for risk-adjusted performance over this period among the 123 newsletters for which the Hulbert Financial Digest had data. But the bear market over the last 18 months has not spared this newsletter. Its portfolios on average lost 48.9% from November 2007 through February of this year. This near halving of its model portfolios is not the only reason that some may question the relevance of the prior period's stellar returns. Repurchase activity itself has considerably dried up. Companies in the S&P 500 index SPX, +1.38% for example, spent just $48.1 billion on buybacks during the fourth quarter of 2008, vs. $141.7 billion in the year-earlier quarter. David Ikenberry, a finance professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, is a co-author of the seminal academic study of buybacks, entitled "Market Underreaction to Open Market Share Repurchases." It appeared in 1995 in the Journal of Financial Economics. In a recent interview, Ikenberry focused on the so-called repurchase effect that his study documented. He summarized the effect as holding that, other things being equal, a company that is repurchasing its shares will tend to outperform the market. But, he stressed, things have most definitely not been equal over the last 18 months, so it is hardly surprising that the repurchase effect has struggled as a stockpicking tool. Ikenberry urged us to remember that share repurchases are discretionary. We therefore would expect buyback programs to be scaled back during a recession, and especially when that recession is coupled with a credit crunch in which companies no longer can be assured of ready access to the capital markets. So even if corporate management were convinced that their share price represented an incredible bargain, they still may not be willing to spend any corporate cash to buy their shares in the open market. Ikenberry mentioned in this regard that some companies have been hoarding cash in recent months rather than spending it on any discretionary expenditures like share buybacks. He predicts that, once concern about access to capital markets begins to abate, much of the corporate cash hoard will find its way into repurchase programs. Ikenberry conceded that, because share repurchases are a relatively recent development in corporate America, we have no prior bear market to study to see what happened then to share repurchases. But he said he seriously doubts that the repurchase effect has stopped working altogether. Ikenberry did pass along one cautionary note, however: It's possible that some companies may be disingenuously announcing the creation of repurchase programs without intending to actually buy back any of their shares. The reason they would do this, of course, is in hopes of boosting their share price. Ikenberry said that, for this reason, investors may want to focus on companies that are actually repurchasing their shares rather than merely announcing that they intend to do so -- companies that his research has shown to perform even better than companies do after announcing share repurchases. The following are the stocks on Fried's March 2009 list of "Buyback Hot List," which he describes as containing "today's most compelling buyback stocks." He stresses that at this point he is merely considering them for possible addition to his newsletter's model portfolios. AAON Inc AAON, +1.04% Alliance Data Systems Corp. ADS, -4.07% Allied World Assurance Holdings AWH, +0.00% CEC Entertainment Inc CEC, +0.24% CF Industrial Holdings Inc CF, +3.40% General Dynamics Corporation GD, +1.67% Granite Construction Inc. GVA, +4.67% Holly Corporation HOC, +0.00% Illinois Tool Works Inc. ITW, +1.82% Infinity Property & Casualty IPCC, +0.51% Insight Enterprises Inc. NSIT, +1.25% IPC Holdings Ltd IPCR J2 Global Communications Inc. JCOM, +2.07% Knight Capital Group Inc. NITE, +2.00% Knoll Inc. KNL, +0.95% McKesson Corporation MCK, +0.15% Odyssey RE Holdings Corp. ORH, -50.00% Seacor Holdings Inc. CKH, +1.41% The Sherwin-Williams Company SHW, +1.78% Sybase Inc. SY, +2.53% Universal Corporation UVV, +1.68% Valeant Pharmaceuticals International VRX, +2.91% More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: Buyback service has suffered, but long-term record's good

content: Toshiba to post 100 billion yen loss on HD-DVD business (9:42 PM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Toshiba Corp.(JP:6501)will take a charge of up to 50 billion yen ($493 million) to discontinue its HD-DVD business and will see total year losses of up to 100 billion yen on the failed technology in the fiscal year ending March 31, according to a published report Thursday. The electronics conglomerate is likely to fall short of its 180 billion yen net profit forecast for the current fiscal year owing to the failure of the HD-DVD format and poor performance in its electronic devices and components unit owing to falling prices for memory chips and other devices, the Nikkei business daily reported, without citing its source. Expenses related to the closure of assembly lines for HD-DVD players and other restructuring costs will amount to 50 billion yen and be booked as a non-operating loss. Toshiba is likely to post an operating profit of 250 billion yen in the current fiscal year, about 40 billion yen shy of its initial forecast, the report said Mens Wearhouse profit drops 72% (4:27 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Mens Wearhouse Inc. MW late Wednesday reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income fell to $14.8 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with net income of $52.3 million, or 95 cents a share. For the quarter ended Feb. 2, sales fell 3.9% to $535 million. Sales at stores open at one year, also known as same-store sales, fell 5.4% in the quarter. For fiscal 2008, Mens Wearhouse is forecasting same-store sales in the U.S. to decline in the "mid single digit range." It pegged full-year earnings between $1.90 to $2.10 a share, which includes the costs of closing a Canadian manufacturing facility. Shares fell 8% in late trading. Energy stocks close to flat line in early action (9:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy stocks traded close to the flat line with slim losses on Wednesday, despite gains in the broader market. The Amex Oil Index XOI, +2.04% fell fractionally at 1,417. The Amex Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% advanced 0.2% to 611. ConocoPhillips COP, +0.95% subtracted 55 cents to $78.95. ConocoPhillips CEO to boost production by 2% a year (8:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ConocoPhillips COP, +0.95% CEO Jim Mulva said the U.S.'s No. 3 oil company plans to boost production by about 2% a year, not including its stake in Lukoil LUK, +1.25% Meeting with Wall Street analysts, Mulva said the company could boost production by 3%, but decided to keep it at the lower level partly to keep costs in line. Looking at reserves, ConocoPhillips will "more than replace" its supplies in years ahead, Mulva said. ConocoPhillips also has lower exposure than others to production sharing contracts with foreign governments, he said. VimpelCom fourth-quarter net profit jumps 86% (8:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- OAO Vimpel Communications VIP, -1.79% Russia's No. 2 cellular operator by user numbers, said Wednesday that fourth-quarter net profit jumped 86% on the year. Net profit was $368.1 million, up from $198.0 million in the year-earlier period. Revenue surged 39% to $2.01 billion from $1.45 billion, as more than 6 million new customers signed up for mobile services. Alfa posts decline in fourth-quarter income (7:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Alfa Corp. ALFA, +2.86% said Wednesday that fourth-quarter net income fell to $18.8 million, or 23 cents a share, from $33 million, or 41 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Total revenue fell to $199.8 million from $209.1 million. Shares of the Montgomery, Ala., insurance and financial services company closed Tuesday at $21.85. Cepheid reaffirms 2008 forecast (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cepheid CPHD said Wednesday that it is reaffirming its prior full-year forecast for net income of $3 million to $5 million, excluding certain items, and revenue of $182 million to $189 million. The Sunnyvale, Calif.-based biotechnology company also said it posted comments on its Web site concerning a recent report in the Journal of the American Medical Association that testing all hospital patients for the fatal staph infection MRSA does not cut the infection rate. "A review of the literature ... over the last 8-10 years shows overwhelming support for the addition of active surveillance programs as part of an overall program to reduce MRSA infections," wrote Chief Executive Officer John Bishop in the Web site posting. "We at Cepheid think that the implementation of such programs will continue in the U.S. and around the world." Shares of Cepheid closed Tuesday at $23.80. AAON profit up 1% on 14% sales growth (7:12 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- AAON Inc. AAON, +1.04% a manufacturer of air-conditioning and heating equipment, said fourth-quarter net income rose 1% to $4.6 million, or 24 cents a share, from $4.5 million, or 24 cents a share, while sales rose 14% to $62.1 million. The company forecast record sales and earnings in the first quarter, but said uncertain market conditions prevented it from making a prediction for the rest of the year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 24 cents a share. Air Berlin drops after saying profit to fall 78% (5:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Shares in low-cost carrier Air Berlin(DE:AB1000)dropped 7.5% after reporting that it's going to earn about 11 million euros ($17 million) in 2007, down 78%, and that its earnings before interest and tax dropped 66.5% to 21.49 million euros, on one-time charges in the double digit millions resulting from the delayed LTU integration and issues associated with the technical integration of the IT systems. The airline, which will release full results on March 31, also noted it won't be able to release certain reserves that it had expected. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected an EBIT of 63.3 million euros and a net profit of 40.4 million euros. Revenue rose a stronger-than-forecast 61% to 2.54 billion euros. J.C. Decaux drops after saying sales growth to slow (5:13 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Shares in outdoor advertising firm J.C. Decaux(FR:007791)dropped 3.8% in Paris after the firm said it expects comparable sales to rise "around 6%" this year, after a slow start in France and the U.K. Comparable sales grew 8.8% in 2007. Its 2007 profit rose a stronger-than-forecast 10% to 221 million euros ($334 million). Deutsche Lufthansa profit more than doubles, hikes dividend (3:54 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German airline Deutsche Lufthansa(DE:823212)said Wednesday that its 2007 net profit more than doubled to 1.66 billion euros from 803 million euros a year earlier as revenue grew 13% to 22.42 billion euros. The bottom line was helped by gains of around 503 million euros from the sale of its shares in Thomas Cook. Operating profit for the year rose 63% to 1.38 billion euros. Growth was also helped by Swiss International Air Lines, which was fully consolidated in the accounts since July. The integration of Swiss led to cost and revenue synergies of 233 million euros, Lufthansa said. It added it plans to raise its dividend by 79% to 1.25 euros a share. Aer Lingus swings to profit, remains cautious on 2008 (3:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Airline operator Aer Lingus Group(UK:AERL)said Wednesday that it swung to a net profit of 105.3 million euros in 2007 from a loss of 69.9 million euros in 2006 as revenue rose 15% to 1.28 billion euros. Excluding one-time charges in the previous year, net profit was up 36%, the company said. Operating profit rose 16.4% to 88.5 million euros, beating expectations. The airline attributed the performance to tighter cost controls in the face of rising oil prices and higher ancillary revenues, including from onboard sales, booking fees and hotel and insurance commissions. The group was cautious about 2008, saying around two-thirds of its fuel requirements remain unhedged against rising costs and adding that revenue per available seat kilometre is expected to fall in the first half. Standard Life underlying profit climbs 53% (3:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. insurer Standard Life(UK:SL)said Wednesday that its underlying profit after tax for 2007 rose 53% to 725 million pounds ($1.46 billion), helped by a stronger performance in U.K. life insurance and pensions as well as lower costs. Pretax operating profit on a European embedded value basis rose 43% to 881 million pounds. The group said it had beaten all its profitability and efficiency targets for 2007. Standard Life said it has made a good start to 2008, considering the uncertain economic environment and added it plans to work on improving its core profitability. The group also raised its full year dividend by 6.5% to 11.5 pence a share. VeraSun 4th-quarter net dropped 81%, revenue doubled (2:43 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- VeraSun Energy Corp., VSE the Brookings, S.D., ethanol producer, reported fourth-quarter net income dropped 81% as revenue more than doubled. Earnings were $4 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with $21.4 million, or 27 cents, in the year-earlier period. Shares outstanding rose 18% to 95 million. Revenue reached $312.3 million from $146.5 million. In the quarter, the company sold 134.4 million gallons of ethanol, more than twice the amount it sold a year earlier, but the price per gallon dropped 30 cents, or 14%, VeraSun said in a statement late on Tuesday. The company markets E85, a blend of 85% ethanol and 15% gasoline for use in flexible-fuel vehicles, to fuel retailers. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- AAON Inc. AAON, +1.04% a manufacturer of air-conditioning and heating equipment, said fourth-quarter net income rose 1% to $4.6 million, or 24 cents a share, from $4.5 million, or 24 cents a share, while sales rose 14% to $62.1 million. The company forecast record sales and earnings in the first quarter, but said uncertain market conditions prevented it from making a prediction for the rest of the year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 24 cents a share.
title: AAON profit up 1% on 14% sales growth

content: Advancers AAON Inc. AAON, +1.04% shares surged 13% Wednesday after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $4.5 million, or 35 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $2.3 million, or 18 cents a share. Sales rose in the latest three months to $54.6 million from $48.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 34 cents a share in the December period. Looking ahead, the Tulsa, Okla., maker of air conditioning and heating equipment said it expects higher sales and earnings in fiscal 2007 compared to its performance in 2006, when it earned $17.1 million, or $1.35 a share, on sales of $231.5 million. Ascent Solar Technologies ASTI, +0.00% shares soared 89% after Norsk Hydro ASA acquired 1.6 million of the company's common shares as a precursor to a strategic relationship between the parties. The private placement represents about 23% of the total shares issued and outstanding after the sale. The purchase was for $9.2 million, or roughly $5.77 per share. The deal also gives Norsk Hydro the option to purchase up to an additional 12% of Ascent's outstanding common stock and a corresponding portion of Class A and Class B warrants. CommScope Inc. CTV, +0.68% shares rose 8.8% after the company raised its first-quarter revenue forecast to $415 million to $425 million from a previous range of $390 million to $410 million, citing trends in sales, orders and operations. The Hickory, N.C., coaxial cable company also boosted its first-quarter operating margin expectation to 12.5% to 13.5% from a previous prediction of 10.5% to 11.5%, excluding any items. Critical Therapeutics CRTX shares leapt 22% after the company entered an agreement with Dey L.P., an affiliate of Germany's Merck KGaA, to jointly promote asthma drug Zyflo, with Dey paying the company a nonrefundable $3 million upfront. According to a filing with the SEC, Critical Therapeutics and Dey have each agreed to contribute a minimum of $3 million a year for expenses in promoting Zyflo, the brand name for zileuton tablets. Friedman Billings Ramsey Group FBR, +1.30% shares gained 7.1% after the company said it plans to begin buying back stock under its existing 14 million share repurchase authorization. The company also plans to explore strategic options for its First NLC non-conformed mortgage origination business. Gymboree Corp. GYMB shares rose 9.1% after the company reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $24.4 million, or 75 cents a share, up from $20.4 million, or 61 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The San Francisco-based children's clothing retailer said revenue in the 14 weeks ended Feb. 3 rose to $241 million from $203.7 million in the comparable period last year. Shares of Lev Pharmaceuticals Inc. LEVP jumped 15% after the company reported positive results of a late-stage trial for its proposed treatment of hereditary angioedema, or HAE. The company said that the primary endpoint of the phase III trial of its C1-esterase inhibitor was reached with a clinically and statistically significant reduction in the time to sustained relief of acute HAE symptoms. Lev now plans to submit a biologic license application for the therapy, which has orphan drug status, to the Food and Drug Administration in the second quarter. Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% shares rose 2.5% after the company said it has agreed to acquire Tellme Networks Inc., a privately-held provider of software for voice-activated services, as part of a development push that could eventually integrate voice commands into numerous Microsoft products. Molecular Insight MIPI shares gained 11% after the company was initiated with an outperform rating at RBC Capital and a buy rating at Jefferies & Co. Sapient Corp. SAPE, -0.08% shares rose 10% after the company said its preliminary results indicated it swung to a fourth-quarter loss of $686,000, or a penny a share, from a profit of $10.5 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding items, earnings were 6 cents a share. The Cambridge, Mass., technology and business consulting firm said revenue increased 38% to $119.2 million from $86.6 million a year ago. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial predicted fourth-quarter revenue of $110.4 million. Sapient predicts first-quarter service revenue of more than $116 million, the company said. SMTC Corp. SMTX, +1.58% shares climbed 13% after the company reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $2.11 million, or 14 cents a share, up from $1.42 million, or 10 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $76.1 million from $58.1 million. Decliners AudioCodes Ltd. AUDC, +2.14% shares fell 22% Wednesday after the company cut its first-quarter earnings and revenue forecast. Canadian Solar Inc. CSIQ, +2.20% shares dropped 14% after the China-based company reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $5.18 million, or 21 cents a share. In the same quarter last year, the company posted a net profit of $688,000, or 4 cents a share. Excluding certain items, the loss in the 2006 fourth quarter came in at $1.67 million, or 7 cents s share. Revenue rose to $24.4 million from $6.8 million. The company forecast 2007 revenue of $220 million to $230 million. Clean Harbors Inc. CLHB shares sank 7.2% after the Norwell, Mass., provider of environmental and hazardous-waste-management services, reported fourth-quarter net income rose 45% on 20% higher revenue. Earnings increased to $11.5 million, or 56 cents a share, from $8 million, or 43 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached $231.8 million from $193.7 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 59 cents of profit on $216 million of revenue. The results reflected "solid demand across our business lines and good weather," Chairman and Chief Executive Alan McKim said in a statement. For the first quarter -- seasonally the company's slowest because of weather conditions -- Clean Harbors expects revenue of $200 million to $205 million. Thomson's survey projects $206 million. For 2007, the Company expects to increase revenue by 8% to 9% from 2006's $829.8 million. Thomson's estimate: $905 million. Diamond Management & Technology Consultants DTPI shares tumbled 25% after the company lowered its outlook for the fourth quarter, citing its failure to win several expected small and moderate sized projects in February and March. The Chicago-based consulting firm now expects earnings from continuing operations of 6 to 7 cents a share for the fourth quarter on revenue of between $41.5 million and $42.5 million. Its previous expectation was for earnings of 8 to 10 cents a share in the period on revenue of $44 million to $47 million. The company also said its board has approved an additional $50 million buyback program. First Consulting FCGI shares sank 19% after the company posted a fourth-quarter profit of $5.1 million, or 19 cents a share, down from its third-quarter profit of $6.1 million, or 23 cents a share. In the year-ago fourth quarter, the company lost $10.2 million, or 41 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for earnings of 21 cents a share in the December period. Genta Inc. GNTA shares fell 21% after the Berkeley, Calif.-based biopharmaceutical company said it has agreed to sell 30 million shares to institutional investors for gross proceeds of roughly $11 million before fees and expenses. Golfsmith International Holdings Inc. GOLF, +0.09% shares sank 11% after the company said its fourth-quarter loss narrowed to $1.57 million, or 10 cents a share, from $2.26 million, or 23 cents a shares, a year earlier. The Austin, Texas, sports equipment retailer's revenue rose to $75 million from $71.8 million in the year-ago period. For the first quarter, the company expects per-share earnings of 20 to 22 cents on revenue of $77 million to $79 million. For 2007, the company expects per-share earnings of 69 to 79 cents on revenue of $417 million to $430 million. Houston Wire & Cable Co. HWCC, +0.34% shares lost 5.6% after the company said certain selling stockholders plan to offer 5.5 million shares of common stock in an underwritten public offering. Participants in the deal include Code, Hennessy & Simmons and Wells Fargo and Co. In connection with the offering, the stockholders granted underwriters an option to purchase up to 825,000 additional shares of common stock to cover over-allotments. Houston Wire & Cable, a distributor of specialty wire and cable, said it won't receive any of the proceeds from the sale of shares by the selling stockholders. William Blair & Co. is acting as sole book-running manager for the offering. MedAvant PILL, +2.74% shares plummeted 40% after the company posted a fourth-quarter loss of $1.6 million, or 12 cents a share, on revenue of $15.8 million, and said it expects its independent auditor to issue a going concern opinion related to its financial statements for the year ended Dec. 31. "Over the last several years we have experienced recurring losses from operations and have limitations on access to capital, however, we are continuing our efforts to reduce costs and increase revenue through execution of our business strategies, new product launches and expanded relationships with certain customers," said John Lettko, the company's president and CEO. Microvision Inc. MVIS, +2.73% shares fell 6% Wednesday after the Redmond, Wash.-based developer of displays and imaging systems late Tuesday reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $8.68 million, or 21 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $5.42 million, or 23 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $1.84 million from $2.71 million. Pope & Talbot POP shares lost 5.2% after the company postponed its year-end 2006 earnings release, previously scheduled for March 15, to April 3. SeaChange International Inc.'s SEAC, +0.37% shares fell 18% after the company said its fiscal fourth-quarter loss widened slightly to $3.75 million, or 13 cents a share, from $3.07 million, or 11 cents a share, a year earlier. The Acton, Mass. digital video systems company's revenue for the quarter ended Jan. 31 rose 21% to $40.1 million from $33.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial estimated, on average, a fourth-quarter loss of 4 cents a share on revenue of $41 million.
