title: Wednesday's biggest stock gainers and decliners

content: Bradley Pharmaceuticals swings to a profit (5:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Bradley Pharmaceuticals BDY late Monday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $1.12 million, or 7 cents a share. In the same quarter last year, the company posted a net loss of $988,683, or 6 cents a share. The Fairfield, N.J.-based company said revenue in the three months ended Dec. 31 rose to $37.7 million from $30.9 million. Zumiez fourth-quarter profit jumps 67% (4:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Zumiez Inc. ZUMZ, +0.00% late Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $11.3 million, or 39 cents a share, up 67% from $6.76 million, or 23 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Everett, Wash.-based action sports apparel and equipment retailer said revenue in the quarter ended Feb. 3 rose 49% to $112.4 million from $75.4 million, while same-store sales rose 12%. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a per-share profit 36 cents on revenue of $111 million. The company forecast fiscal 2007 earnings of 94 cents to 96 cents a share, and said its long-term financial targets include same-store sales growth in the mid single-digit range, net square footage expansion of roughly 20%, and diluted earnings-per-share growth of more than 30%. Analysts are looking for a fiscal 2007 profit of 92 cents a share. Hibbett Sports quarterly profit rises 27% (4:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hibbett Sports Inc. HIBB, +2.35% late Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $12.6 million, or 39 cents a share, up 27% from $9.9 million, or 29 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Birmingham, Ala.-based sporting goods chain said revenue in the quarter ended Feb. 3 rose to $151.2 million from $120.8 million in the comparable period last year, while same-store sales rose 5.9%. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a per-share profit of 38 cents on revenue of $150 million. For the first quarter, the company expects earnings of 32 cents to 35 cents a share and for same-store sales to fall 1% to 3%. For fiscal 2008, Hibbett forecast earnings of $1.30 to $1.35 a share on a same-store sales increase of 2% to 4% range. Analysts expect a first-quarter per-share profit of 41 cents and a fiscal 2008 per-share profit of $1.39. Hot Topic quarterly profit falls 16% (4:06 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hot Topic Inc. HOTT late Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $8.87 million, or 20 cents a share, down 16% from $10.6 million, or 23 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The City of Industry, Calif.-based teen apparel retailer said revenue in the quarter ended Feb. 3 rose to $240.5 million from $230.4 million in the comparable period last year, while same-store sales fell 5.3%. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a per-share profit of 21 cents on revenue of $239 million. NPS Pharma quarterly loss narrows; plans job cuts (1:41 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- NPS Pharmaceuticals Inc. NPSP on Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $14 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $44.3 million, or 96 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The company posted revenue of $24.1 million vs. $4.31 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast a fourth-quarter loss of 36 cents a share. NPS Pharma also said it plans to reduce its current staff to 35 employees from 196 by the end of 2007. The company said it will close facilities in Salt Lake City and Toronto and consolidate its operations in New Jersey. Additionally, NPS Pharma said it plans to reduce 2007 cash burn to about $85 million to $95 million, including restructuring and non-recurring expenses, from $113 million in 2006. The company said it sees 2008 cash burn of $35 million to $45 million. NPS Pharma said it plans to reduce the size of its board 7 directors from 10. The company said that current directors Santo Costa, Joseph Klein and company founder, Hunter Jackson, don't plan to stand for re-election to the board at the annual meeting. Microvision net loss widens; shares fall (11:00 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Microvision Inc. MVIS, +2.73% shares fell 7.1% to $3.28 in Wednesday morning trade. Late Tuesday, the Redmond, Wash.-based developer of displays and imaging systems reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $8.68 million, or 21 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $5.42 million, or 23 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $1.84 million from $2.71 million. First Consulting shares fall as company swings to a profit (10:26 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- First Consulting Group Inc. [sL fcgi] shares fell 14% to $10.03 in Wednesday morning trade. Late Tuesday, the Long Beach, Calif.-based outsourcing services provider reported that it swung to a fourth-quarter net profit of $5.09 million, or 19 cents a share, from a net loss of $10.2 million, or 41 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $69.8 million from $73.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a per-share profit of 21 cents. First Consulting expects first-quarter revenue of $64 million to $66 million with continued operating profitability and positive cash flow. The company added that it expects first-quarter pre-tax operating profit to be lower than it was in the fourth quarter. Retail shares slip in early trading, RadioShack weak (9:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Retail shares slipped early Wednesday, led by weakness in home electronics retailer RadioShack Corp. RSH, -0.07% Nordstrom Inc. JWN, +1.06% and Staples Inc. SPLS On the upside, shares of pharmacy operators CVS Corp. CVS, -0.80% and Walgreen Co. WAG rose. CVS shareholders are slated to vote on the company's proposed acquisition of pharmacy benefits manager Caremark Rx Inc. CMX, -9.09% on Thursday. The S&P Retail Index $RLX slipped fractionally to 499.85. Discounters could be pinched by subprime woes: analyst (9:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Discount retailers and dollar stores could face "modest headwinds" in the face of concerns about the subprime market, as some of their customer base may put off non-essential spending to meet rising debt payments, Citigroup analyst Deborah Weinswig wrote in a note to clients on Wednesday. Citing Citigroup economist Steven Wieting, the note said the concerns for broadline retailers could be overdone, because subprime borrowers only account for about 4% of households and 2% of consumer spending. Consumption trends are not expected to be impacted, the note said. "However, he cautions that rising interest payments for the subprime borrower will likely stress household finances and could impact spending." H&R Block falls, discloses $29 mln loss tied to mortgages (9:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- H&R Block HRB, +1.03% shares fell 8% to $18.70 in pre-market trades Wednesday after it disclosed an additional $29 million loss on top of what it reported Feb. 22 in its preliminary release of its financial results. The company cited recent market conditions resulting in "significant declines" in the value of mortgage loans, including the value of non-performing loans. "Due to rapidly declining loan values in the current environment, that evaluation resulted in significantly lower modeled cash flows, and a corresponding increase to impairment of residual interests for the quarter," the company said. Baxter: R&D investment to exceed sales for next five years (8:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Baxter International Inc. BAX, +1.86% on Wednesday said its investment in research and development, which totaled a record $614 million in 2006, will continue to increase at a greater rate than sales growth over the next five years. Several research and development programs that the company will showcase at an investor conference include: regenerative medicine initiatives in stem cell therapy and hard and soft tissue repair products; cell-based vaccines; biotherapeutic treatments for Alzheimer's and other neurological diseases; and medication delivery products with special antimicrobial coatings to reduce bloodstream infections. Deerfield, Ill.-based Baxter said that through 2011, its financial objectives include compound annual sales growth of at least 6% to 8%, and growth in earnings per share of at least 11% to 13%. In addition, the company expects annual cash flow from operations to approach about $3 billion over the period. Clean Harbors 4th-quarter net rose 45%, revenue up 20% (8:02 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Clean Harbors Inc., CLHB the Norwell, Mass., provider of environmental and hazardous-waste-management services in North America, reported fourth-quarter net income rose 45% on 20% higher revenue. Earnings rose to $11.5 million, or 56 cents a share, from $8 million, or 43 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached $231.8 million from $193.7 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 59 cents of profit on $216 million of revenue. The results reflected "solid demand across our business lines and good weather," Chairman and Chief Executive Alan McKim said in a statement. For the first quarter -- seasonally the company's slowest because of weather conditions -- Clean Harbors expects revenue of $200 million to $205 million. Thomson's survey projects $206 million. For 2007, the Company expects to increase revenue by 8% to 9% from 2006's $829.8 million. Thomson's estimate: $905 million. AAON fourth-quarter profit $4.5 mln vs $2.3 mln (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AAON Inc. AAON, +1.04% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $4.5 million, or 35 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $2.3 million, or 18 cents a share. Sales rose in the latest three months to $54.6 million from $48.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 34 cents a share in the December period. Looking ahead, the Tulsa, Okla., maker of air conditioning and heating equipment said it expects higher sales and earnings in fiscal 2007 compared to its performance in 2006, when it earned $17.1 million, or $1.35 a share, on sales of $231.5 million. The stock closed Tuesday at $24.69, down 5.2%. Biolase Technology posts quarterly profit; revenue up 5% (6:54 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Biolase Technology Inc. BLTI reported fourth-quarter net income of $1 million, or 4 cents a share, a reversal from the dental-laser company's net loss of $1.2 million, or 5 cents a share, in the final three months of 2005. Quarterly revenue rose 5%, reaching $19.8 million, the Irvine, Calif.-based company said. Earnings for the latest quarter benefited from $417,000 in license-fee revenue generated from the amortization of a $5 million payment received from Henry Schein Inc. HSIC, +1.42% last August. Analysts, on average, had been looking for Biolase to turn in a quarterly loss of 1 cent a share on revenue of $20 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. Shares of Biolase added 43 cents, or 5%, to end Tuesday's trading at $9.05. Stage Stores' quarterly net target above consensus (6:21 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Stage Stores Inc. SSI, -0.46% said it's aiming for earnings of 31 cents to 35 cents a share for the first quarter ending May 5. Quarterly sales are pegged at $372 million to $380 million. And for the full year, the retailer's looking to generate a profit of $1.45 to $1.55 a share on sales of nearly $1.62 billion to nearly $1.66 billion. Analysts' average profit estimates, as compiled by Thomson Financial, stand at 26 cents a share for the first quarter and $1.53 a share for the fiscal year. As for sales, the average estimates for Stage Stores are $374 million for the first quarter and nearly $1.65 billion for the year. The company noted that it anticipates recording an additional gain during the current quarter from the sale of the Peebles private-label credit-card portfolio of 4 cents a share. Stage Stores' profit jumps as quarterly sales increase 17.3% (6:11 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Stage Stores Inc. SSI, -0.46% reported net income of $39.6 million, or 88 cents a share, for the fourth quarter ended Feb. 3, up from $19.7 million, or 45 cents, earned in the year-earlier period. The rural-oriented retailer's sales rose 17.3%, reaching $491.2 million from $418.6 million, in part reflecting an additional week in the most recent 14-week quarter. Comparable-store sales during the first 13 weeks of the latest quarter grew 2.5%, Houston-based Stage Stores said. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of 87 cents a share and sales of $491 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. Shares of Stage Stores lost 73 cents, or 3.3%, to end Tuesday's trading at $21.41. Elbit Systems swings to 4th-quarter profit; revenue up 45% (5:09 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Elbit Systems Ltd., ESLT, +1.72% the Tel Aviv defense contractor, reported that it swung to a fourth-quarter profit from a year-earlier loss on 45% higher revenue. The company earned $24 million, or 57 cents a share, compared with a loss of $5.7 million, or 14 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached $467.4 million from $321.8 million. Elbit said its gross-profit margin narrowed in the quarter to 21.4% from 24.4%, with results from its 70%-owned Elisra Electronic Systems Ltd. subsidiary knocking 3.8 percentage points off the figure. President and Chief Executive Joseph Ackerman said in a statement that Elbit would continue its turnaround effort at Elisra. The backlog at Dec. 31 was up 13% at $3.79 billion. Leader & Co. analysts, in a brief note, called the report "disappointing," saying the "strong" revenue figure was offset by the difficulties at Elisra. The firm reiterated its market-perform rating on the stock. Germany's Hypo '06 net up 43%; sees '07 pretax profit up 20% (3:50 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Hypo Real Estate Group,(DE:802770)the Munich real-estate-financing and investment-banking group, reported 2006 net income rose 43% pretax profit rose 29% and revenue rose 14%, and it estimated at least a 20% rise in pretax profit for 200. Hypo's net reached 542 million euros ($712.7 million) in 2006, compared with the figure of 380 million euros in 2005. Profit before taxes rose to 571 million euros from 443 million. Revenue rose to 1.08 billion euros from 946 million. For 2007, the company expects to earn at least 680 million euros before taxes, as the provision for losses on loans and advances totals 150 million to 160 million euros, about steady with 2006 levels. Revenue for 2007 should exceed 1.2 billion euros, Hypo estimated. Informa profit jumps, CEO to succeed chairman in May (3:48 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Publishing group Informa Plc(UK:INF)on Wednesday announced a sharp jump in 2006 net profit as it also set out the succession plan to replace its retiring chairman. Informa said profit jumped to 67.8 million pounds from 10.8 million pounds as revenue rose 42% to 1.04 billion pounds, driven by the acquisition of events organizer IIR. Informa added it expects underlying strength to counter weakness in the dollar, allowing it to achieve its targets in 2007. The firm also announced that chief executive Peter Rigby will succeed Richard Hooper as chairman when Hooper retires in May. It added managing director David Gilbertson will become Chief Executive. While recognizing that appointing the CEO as chairman runs against corporate governance best practice, the company said it has done so to ensure stability after three years of fundamental changes. French Connection profit tumbles, sees start of new cycle (3:47 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. retailer French Connection(UK:FCCN)said its profit before tax in 2006 dropped to 4 million pounds from 12.2 million pounds, with revenue down 2% to 241 million pounds. The company said its spring/summer 2006 line hurt profits and it's holding its dividend flat at 5 pence a share. But it added there is "good evidence" to indicate that it's at the start of a new phase in its business cycle. French broadband supplier Iliad reports 80% profit rise (3:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Iliad(FR:ILD), the French broadband provider, said its profit rose an above-forecast 80% to 124 million euros ($163 million), with revenue up 31% to 950 million euros. Iliad is aiming to exceed 2.8 million ADSL subscribers by the end of the year and increase its unbundling ratio to 80%. It's going to pay a 0.27 euros a share dividend. The company last night said Michael Boukobkza will leave as chief executive this summer for "personal projects," to be replaced by Maxime Lombardini, who previously worked for broadcaster TF1. Stagecoach gives bullish update, plans 700 mln pound payout (3:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. bus and rail company Stagecoach Group(UK:SGC)said Wednesday that it intends to return 700 million pounds ($1.35 billion) to shareholders and also announced it expects its profit for the year to be at the top end of its expectations. Stagecoach said it will pay shareholders 63 pence a share -- equivalent to 40% of its market capitalization -- through the issue of B and C shares following the elimination of its debt and a revue of its capital structure. Stagecoach had previously said it planned to return at least 400 million pounds. The company said performance has improved across all its divisions, partly due to lower fuel prices. It also said its prospects for the year ending April 30, 2008 have further improved, especially in its U.K. bus operations and its Virgin Rail Group joint venture. Engineering group Amec's loss widens on lawsuits, exit costs (3:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. engineering group Amec(UK:AMEC)said its loss before tax in 2006 widened to 109 million pounds ($211 million) from 17.7 million pounds, mainly on a 170 million pound charge for lawsuits and separation costs. From continuing operations, its adjusted earnings per share fell 17% to 14.5 pence a share and revenue rose 14% to 3.22 billion pounds, which the company said was in line with an update from December. It's upped its dividend by 6% to 12.2 pence a share, and its divestment of non-core businesses is expected by the end of the year. Insulation products provider SIG pretax profit climbs 23% (3:24 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- SIG(UK:SHI), a European supplier of insulation, roofing and commercial interiors products, said its profit before tax from continuing operations increased by 22.6% to 103 million pounds ($199 million), with sales up 17% to 1.93 billion pounds. Analysts polled by Factset JCF expected a pretax profit of 111.5 million pounds on revenue of 1.86 billion pounds. It's upping its dividend 22% to 20.5p a share. Home Retail sees annual results slightly above forecast (3:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. retailer Home Retail(UK:HOME)said it expects annual results to be "slightly above" the current market consensus, driven principally by Argos. Analysts polled by Factset JCF expect a profit before tax of 344 million pounds. In the eight weeks to March 3, Argos same-store sales rose 3%, while Homebase same-store sales climbed 9.9%. The company said it remain cautious on a retail environment that is still expected to be challenging. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AAON Inc. AAON, +1.04% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $4.5 million, or 35 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $2.3 million, or 18 cents a share. Sales rose in the latest three months to $54.6 million from $48.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 34 cents a share in the December period. Looking ahead, the Tulsa, Okla., maker of air conditioning and heating equipment said it expects higher sales and earnings in fiscal 2007 compared to its performance in 2006, when it earned $17.1 million, or $1.35 a share, on sales of $231.5 million. The stock closed Tuesday at $24.69, down 5.2%.
title: AAON fourth-quarter profit $4.5 mln vs $2.3 mln

content: Advancers AAON Inc. AAON, +1.04% shares rose 5.8% after the company was upgraded to buy from neutral at Sidoti & Co. Advanced Auto Parts AAP, +2.22% shares climbed 5.3% after the company said third-quarter net income for the three months ended Oct. 7 fell to $58.9 million, or 56 cents a share, from $60.8 million, or 55 cents a share in the year-ago period. The latest quarter includes 3 cents a share in stock option expense. Revenue rose to $1.1 billion from $1 billion. AMN Healthcare AHS, -9.09% shares gained 8.4% after the company boosted its financial outlook for the full year, citing a strong third-quarter performance. The San Diego-based provider of temporary healthcare staffing services now expects earnings of 94 to 96 cents a share for the year, including a charge of 12 cents a share for stock option expense, on revenue of between $1.07 billion and $1.08 billion. Blockbuster Inc. BBI, +4.00% shares jumped 9.8% after the company posted a loss of $24.7 million, or 15 cents a share, in the third quarter, narrower than the $491.4 million, or $2.67 a share, lost in the year-ago quarter. The improvement was mainly due to non-cash charges booked in the 2005 third quarter to impair goodwill and other items. The adjusted loss was 8 cents a share compared with a loss of 14 cents a year ago. Revenue fell 2.9% to $1.33 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 11 cents and revenue of $1.31 billion. Cabot Corp. CBT, +2.14% shares gained 10% after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $27 million, or 39 cents a share, up from a year-ago loss of $59 million, or $1.02 a share. Callaway Golf Co. ELY, +0.62% shares moved up 5.4% after the company was upgraded to buy from hold at A.G. Edwards. Citi Trends CTRN, +0.13% shares leapt 17% after the company said its October sales at stores open at least one year fell 4%. Analysts, on average, had expected it to post a same-store sales drop of 6.2%, according to Thomson First Call. Total net sales for the four weeks ended Oct. 28 rose 15% to $26 million. For the third quarter, comparable sales increased 6.2%, the Savannah, Ga.-based retailer said. Total net sales for the 13-week period ended Oct. 28 rose 25% to $87.1 million. Clark CLK shares jumped 31% after the company agreed to be acquired by the U.S. unit of Aegon NV AEG, +0.15% for about $293 million, or $16.55 per share. CoTherix CTRX shares jumped 13% after the Brisbane, Calif.-based pharmaceutical company late Wednesday reported a third-quarter net loss of $2.84 million, or 10 cents a share, narrower than a net loss of $6.16 million, or 26 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding items, CoTherix reported a loss of $1.1 million, or 4 cents a share, vs. a loss of $5.1 million, or 22 cents a share, last year. Revenue rose to $18.4 million from $8.41 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast a per-share loss of 32 cents on revenue of $18.2 million. The company expects 2007 Ventavis sales of $100 million to $105.5 million. Friedman Billings Ramsey Group FBR, +1.30% shares gained 7.8% after the company said it lost $67.4 million, or 39 cents a share in the third quarter ended Sept. 30, compared to net income of $23 million, or 14 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Arlington, Va. firm took a $146.8 million non-cash mark-to-market write-down in the value of its mortgage portfolio. It also recognized a $20 million non-cash write-down of equity positions in its merchant banking portfolio, the majority of which involve companies doing business in the non-prime mortgage sector. Two analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 17 cents a share. Guess Inc. GES, -0.81% shares climbed 13% after the company said third-quarter net income rose, as revenue gained, to $48.4 million, or $1.05 a share, from $20.7 million, or 46 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Analysts had expected per-share income of 72 cents. Hot Topic Inc. HOTT shares rose 6.8% after the company lowered its fourth-quarter earnings expectations after reporting that October same-store sales fell more than Wall Street expected. Sales at stores open longer than a year tumbled 7.2%, deeper than the 5.7% decline estimated by analysts. Metal Management MM, -0.50% shares leapt 14% after the company posted fiscal second-quarter earnings of $29.1 million, or $1.09 a share, up from a year-ago profit of $16.9 million, or 66 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 68 cents a share in the September period from the Chicago metal recycler. Microvision MVIS, +2.73% shares jumped 28% after the Redmond, Wash., light scanning technology company said it's signed a joint development agreement with an undisclosed major Asian consumer electronics manufacturer. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Mid-State Bancshares MDST shares gained 24% after the company agreed to be acquired by Rabobank, a Dutch financial services provider, for $851 million, or roughly $37 per share in cash. The Roseville, Calif., holding company for Mid-State Bank & Trust said it expects the deal to close in the second quarter. As of Sept. 30, the bank had total assets of $2.37 billion. Millipore Inc. MIL, -3.92% shares gained 5.2% after the company was upgraded to buy from neutral at UBS. The firm also lifted its price target to $87 from $73, citing optimism about the company's long-term outlook. Morningstar Inc. MORN, +0.72% shares rose 7.1% after the company said its third-quarter net income rose to $13.5 million, or 29 cents a share, from $7.5 million, or 17 cents a share a year earlier. The Chicago-based investment research firm Thursday said quarterly revenue rose 44% to $81.8 million, including $11.6 million in sales from acquisitions completed in 2006. A pair of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected profit of 28 cents a share. Plexus Corp. PLXS, +2.10% shares jumped 20% after the company said fourth-quarter net income rose, as revenue gained, to $42.6 million, or 91 cents a share, from $10.5 million, or 24 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Quarterly revenue rose to $396.9 million from $322.2 million, while analysts had expected $397.8 million. Skyworks Solutions Inc. SWKS, +1.41% shares rose 6% after the company said fourth-quarter per-share income, before items, rose to 7 cents from 4 cents in the prior year, while analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected 5 cents. Quarterly revenue rose to $193.1 million from $190.2 million in the prior year. Tekelec TKLC shares gained 8.4% after the company was upgraded to buy from hold at Morgan Joseph & Co. ValueClick Inc. VCLK shares added 14% after the company reported third-quarter profit rose 52%, exceeding expectations, as it benefited from the growth in online advertising. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, profit increased to $16.8 million, or 17 cents a share, from earnings of $11 million or 13 cents a share a year ago. Warnaco Group WRNC shares leapt 11% after the company was upgraded to outperform from market perform at Piper Jaffray. The firm also lifted its price target on the stock to $25 from $19. WellCare Health Plans WCG, +1.77% shares surged 7.6% after the health insurer reported third-quarter earnings and revenue that more than doubled ad lifted its full-year forecast far above Wall Street's average expectations. See full story. Xoma Ltd. XOMA, +1.86% shares rose 8.2% after the company agreed to partner with Japan's Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. on the research and development of therapeutic antibodies. The deal calls for payments from Takeda to Xoma that could exceed $100 million. Decliners 24/7 Real Media Inc. TFSM shares tumbled 13% Thursday after the company was downgraded to hold from buy at Wedbush Morgan. The firm cut its price target to $10 from $12. Chico's FAS Inc. CHS, +0.33% shares lost 8% after the company said it's cutting its third-quarter earnings outlook after October sales at stores open at least one year fell 4.1% from a year ago. Analysts, on average, had expected the retailer to post a gain of 0.8%, according to Thomson First Call. Total sales for the four-week period ended October 28 increased 9.9% to $125.3 million. The apparel retailer said it is reducing its third-quarter earnings forecast to a range of 22 cents to 25 cents a share. The current Thomson First Call average estimate is for earnings of 26 cents a share. Christopher & Banks Corp. CBK, +1.90% shares lost 14% after the cmpany said October same-store sales fell 3% from year-earlier levels. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting same-store sales growth of 5.4%. Total sales for the month rose 5% to $53 million from $50.7 million. The Minneapolis women's apparel retailer lowered its fiscal third-quarter earnings estimate to 24 to 25 cents a share from its previous forecast of 31 to 32 cents a share, assuming November same-store sales are similar to October levels. Energizer Holdings ENR, +12.35% shares lost 6.2% after the compny said fiscal fourth-quarter earnings declined to $39.1 million, or 66 cents a share, from $51.8 million, or 72 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding non-recurring items, such as restructuring and pension cost charges and a tax benefit from foreign losses, earning would have been 82 cents a share. Revenue rose 5% to $830.1 million from last year's $793.7 million, as increased battery sales offset flat razor and blade sales. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 76 cents a share and revenue of $821.8 million, on average. The St. Louis battery and razor maker plans to initiate further price increases in an effort to offset rising materials costs. The company sees per-unit gross margins to remain unfavorable until the price increases take effect. Entergis ENTG, +2.05% shares fell 11% after the Chaska, Minn.-based materials integrity management company reported third-quarter net earnings of $17.8 million, or 13 cents a share. Excluding items, the company reported a profit of $21.9 million, or 16 cents a share. In the same quarter last year, the company posted a net loss of $18 million, or 16 cents a share. Revenue rose to $171.3 million from $121.3 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast a per-share profit of 17 cents on revenue of $177.5 million. Entegris forecast a fourth-quarter per-share profit of 9 to 12 cents, or 11 to 14 cents excluding items, on revenue of $155 million to $163 million. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of 17 cents on revenue of $178.9 million. Exelixis EXEL, -0.94% shares dropped 12% after the company suspended patient enrollment in the phase II clinical trial of XL999 until further data have been collected and analyzed, citing cardiovascular adverse events. The company said it anticipated that the suspension will incur a delay in the clinical program for the drug of between two weeks and three months. Intest Corp. INTT, +0.00% shares tumbled 30% after the company posted third-quarter earnings of $508,000, or 6 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $1.9 million, or 21 cents a share. The Cherry Hill, N.J., maker of semiconductor testing equipment said it's entered the down portion of the current business cycle with bookings falling to $13 million in the September quarter from $20.4 million in the previous period. LoJack LOJN shares fell 12% after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $5.2 million, or 28 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $5.8 million, or 30 cents a share. On a pro forma basis, excluding stock option expense, the Westwood, Mass., maker of car theft protection devices earned 31 cents a share in the latest quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 33 cents a share in the September period. Magna Entertainment Corp. MECA shares fell 5.6% after the company said its third-quarter loss widened to $50.7 million, or 47 cents a share, from $34.5 million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 44% to $113.7 million. MarineMax HZO, +2.10% share lost 11% after the company said fourth-quarter net income rose to $12.6 million, or 66 cents a share, from $10.2 million, or 54 cents a share. Revenue rose 42% to $324 million, with same-store sales up 24%. It took 5 cents a share in stock option compensation expenses during the quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected earnings of 69 cents a share. The recreational boat retailer lowered its fiscal 2007 forecast by 10 cents a share on both ends, to $2.05 to $2.15 a share, with same-store sales in the single digits. Analysts had seen earnings of $2.22 a share. Nordstrom Inc. JWN, +1.06% said same-store sales rose 10.7% in October. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for an increase of 6.2% for the month. Occam Networks OCNW shares dropped 18% after the company priced a follow-on offering of 5.25 million shares of its common stock at $14 each. The deal includes an over-allotment option for the sale of an additional 787,500 shares. Peak International PEAK shares tumbled 16% after the company posted a loss of $1.1 million, or 9 cents a share, as sales fell 4.7% to $15.8 million. Hong Kong-based Peak saw reduced sales of its integrated circuit trays and disc caddies. Ruth's Chris Steak House Inc. RUTH, +1.24% shares lost 6.3% after the company said third-quarter net income rose, as revenue gained, to $2.33 million, or 10 cents a share, from $1.23 million, or 2 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Excluding items, quarterly per-share income from continuing operations fell to 8 cents from 10 cents in the prior year. Secure Computing SCUR shares dropped 8.9% after the company was downgraded to sector perform from outperform at RBC Capital Markets. Sharper Image Corp. SHRP shares lost 12% after the company said same-store sales fell 31% in October. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a decrease of 16.6% for the month. Total sales for October dropped 17% to $38.1 million from $46.1 million in the same period a year earlier. SRA International SRX, +7.69% shares fell 14% after the company reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $15.1 million, or 26 cents a share, on revenue of $304 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 29 cents a share from the Fairfax, Va., technology consulting services provider on revenue of $327.7 million. Sunstone Hotel Investors SHO, +0.13% shares lost 7% after the company was downgraded to hold from buy at Deutsche Bank. The firm lowered its price target on the shares to $30 from $34. Universal Truckload Services UACL shares fell 13% after the company was downgraded to peer perform from outperform at Bear Stearns. UTStarcom UTSI, +2.71% shares dropped 11% after the company was downgraded to sell from neutral at Merrill Lynch, saying the share price has almost doubled from its lows in June, but that it sees little evidence that the company's business model has improved so drastically. The broker told clients it continues to believe that the company's outlook hinges on the development of the IPTV in China and possibly other parts of the world. Wilson The Leather Experts WLSN shares lost 8.3% after the company said October same-store sales fell 13.5%. Total sales for the month dipped to $25 million from $29.9 million a year ago. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Thursday's biggest stock gainers and decliners

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Aaon Inc. AAON, +1.04% Tuesday said its board has initiated a semi-annual cash dividend of 20 cents a share, payable on July to shareholders of record on June 12. The Tulsa, Okla., maker of air conditioners and heating equipment also said its board has approved the suspension of its buyback program. The stock closed Monday at $20.73, up a penny.
title: Aaon oks semi-annual dividend; suspends buyback program

content: Advancers Shares of Alpharma Inc. ALO, -1.52% ended Tuesday 52.5% higher after the company reported late Monday earnings of 38 cents a share on revenue of $367.9 million. Excluding special items, earnings would have been 39 cents a share, vs. the average analyst forecast compiled by Thomson First Call of 9 cents a share. Revenue was expected to be $340.3 million. Shares of Aristotle Corp. ARTL, +0.00% surged 12.9% after the maker of educational, health and agricultural products reported second-quarter earnings that rose to $2.6 million, or 15 cents a share from $1.6 million, or 9 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $50.2 million from last year's $44.6 million, due primarily to strength in its educational business. Cash generation improved to $8.1 million from last year's $5.9 million. The stock was last up 83 cents at $7.12. Checkpoint Systems Inc. CKP, -1.02% rocketed 23.4% higher after reporting second-quarter earnings Tuesday of $9.5 million, or 25 cents a share, reversing a $6.4 million, 17 cents a share loss for the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $210.4 million from $189.3 million. Excluding restructuring charges, income was 36 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call was for earnings of 25 cents a share. See full story. Hong Kong oil and gas company CNOOC Ltd. CEO, +0.49% added 6% after it said it has withdrawn its bid to buy Unocal Corp. UCL, +0.00% due primarily to the political opposition that followed its bid, which CNOOC called "regrettable and unjustified." CNOOC noted that its $18.5 billion cash bid, which it said was for "purely commercial objectives," represented a $1 billion premium to Chevron's CVX, +1.73% bid for Unocal. The company added that it would have improved its bid, but was held back by the political opposition. Gen-Probe Inc. GPRO, -1.03% tacked on 9.1% after it reported second-quarter net earnings of $13.5 million, or 26 cents a share, up from $11.8 million, or 23 cents a share, last year. Revenue was $72.9 million vs. $61.2 million last year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 24 cents a share and revenue of $67.3 million. The medical diagnostics product maker also raised its 2005 revenue forecast to $292 million to $300 million and sees earnings of $1.20 to $1.24 a share, excluding the effect of stock-options expensing. Group 1 Auto shares GPI, +3.01% were driven up 11.4% after the auto seller reported second-quarter earnings of $18.1 million, or 75 cents a share, up from $15.7 million, or 67 cents a share, a year before, and above analyst projections of 71 cents a share. Revenue rose 20% to $1.58 billion from $1.31 billion. The company expects 2005 earnings of $2.95 to $3.02 a share, ahead of analyst forecasts of $2.92 a share. Herbalife HLF, +0.31% rallied 20.7% after the company reported second-quarter earnings that rose to $22.8 million, or 32 cents a share from last year's $12.1 million, or 22 cents a share. The results included a $5.5 million charge related to the moving of its China subsidiary. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 27 cents a share. Revenue rose 19% to $384.7 million. The company raised its 2005 earnings forecast to $1.45 to $1.50 a share. Kinder Morgan Inc. KMI, +1.69% surged 6.9% after it said late Monday that it plans to buy Canada's Terasen Inc. (TER) in a $5.6 billion deal that would expand the Houston-based company's natural-gas and petroleum pipeline operations in North America. See full story. Maxim Integrated Products MXIM, +2.15% gained 8.3% after it reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that rose to 37 cents a share from 36 cents a share in the year-earlier period and matched analyst forecasts. Revenue slipped about 5% to $400.4 million, while bookings rose 7% to $398 million. See full story. Myogen MYOG ran up 21.6% after it said late Monday that it expects top-line results from its ARIES-2 trial, which completed patient enrollment on July 21, by the end of 2005. The company also expects to report top line results from the Phase IIb trial for Darusentan by the end of August. Separately, the company reported a second-quarter loss of $21.5 million, or 60 cents a share, vs. a loss of $13.2 million, or 50 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue fell to $2.3 million from last year's $2.6 million. PPL Corp. PPL, +0.43% rose 6.1% after it announced a 2-for-1 stock split, raised its quarterly dividend and lifted its long-term earnings growth forecast to 6% to 7% from 3% to 5%. The company also reported second-quarter earnings, excluding non-recurring items that would have been 91 cents a share topping analyst forecasts of 81 cents. Revenue rose to $1.48 billion from last year's $1.36 billion. See full story. Tenet Healthcare Corp. THC, +1.76% advanced 5.3% after saying it narrowed its second-quarter net loss to $21 million, or 4 cents a share, from $426 million, or 91 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Excluding discontinued operations, the company would have broken even on a per share basis, while analysts had been anticipating a loss of 3 cents a share. Revenue for the period declined to $2.42 billion from $2.5 billion a year ago. The company reiterated that the filing of its 10-Q form is likely to be delayed by developments arising out of the previously disclosed investigation by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. See full story. TRW Automotive Holdings TRW, -3.33% hiked up 7% after it reported second-quarter earnings of $85 million, or 83 cents a share, up from $76 million, or 75 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 73 cents a share. Revenue rose to $3.37 billion from last year's $3.16 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 37 cents a share and revenue of $3.29 billion, on average. For 2005, the auto parts maker expects earnings excluding non-recurring items of $1.50 to $1.70 a share, vs. analyst estimates of $1.57 a share, and revenue of $12.5 billion to $12.9 billion, vs. analyst projections of $12.62 billion. Shares of United Therapeutics UTHR, +1.68% climbed 26.3% to after the drugmaker reported better-than-expected second-quarter results. Earnings rose to $12.2 million, or 49 cents a share from $4.1 million, or 18 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and topped the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 33 cents a share. Revenue increased 64% to $30.1 million, topping analyst forecasts of $25.4 million. Deutsche Bank analyst Jennifer Chao followed by raising her stock price target to $68 from $64 on the "blowout" results, and reiterated her buy rating. Decliners AAON Inc. shares AAON, +1.04% ended the session down 11.4% after the air conditioner and heating equipment maker reported second-quarter earnings of $3.1 million, or 24 cents a share, up from $1.6 million, or 12 cents a share in the year-earlier period, but below analyst forecasts of 30 cents a share, according to an average of 2 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 5.5% to $45.4 million, below one analyst's forecast of $49.5 million. Cooper Tire & Rubber Co. CTB, -0.17% dropped 12.4% after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings of 10 cents to 14 cents a share. Excluding the impact of the Texarkana strike, earnings would be 18 cents to 22 cents a share. Analysts had been projecting earnings of 24 cents a share, on average. For the second quarter, the company reported a loss of $6.88 million, or 11 cents a share, compared to $33 million in net income, or 46 cents a share, for the same period last year. Adjusted earnings would have been 4 cents a share. Revenues fell less than 1% to $509 million, down from $511 million during the same period last year. The Findlay, Ohio-based tire maker was expected to earn 3 cents a share. See full story. Shares of Evolving Systems EVOL, -1.75% dropped 14.7% after the wireless communications software company lowered its 2005 revenue forecast to $40 million to $46 million from $44 million to $50 million. For the second-quarter, company reported a loss of $689,000, or 4 cents a share, wider than the year-earlier loss of $168 million, or a penny a share. Revenue nearly doubled to $9.9 million from $5.3 million in the same period a year ago. Foot Locker FL, +1.70% fell 6.3% after the shoe seller lowered its fiscal second-quarter earnings forecast to 27 to 29 cents a share, below analyst forecasts of 35 cents a share, due primarily to disappointing results from its European business. The company said same-store sales for the quarter rose 1.3% and total sales increased to $1.31 billion from last year's $1.27 billion. Read more. Macrovision Corp. MVSN dropped 17.3% after the company cut late Monday its financial outlook for the year, saying the DVD industry "appears to have hit a few road bumps" that will impact its copyright protection business. For the second quarter, the company reported revenue that rose 25% to $44.4 million, but fell short of analyst forecasts of $47.9 million. Earnings fell to 12 cents a share, from last year's 18 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the company would have earned 16 cents a share, matching analyst estimates. See full story. Shares of Masco Corp. MAS, +1.53% were knocked 5% lower after the home improvement and building products maker said it expects third-quarter earnings of 60 to 64 cents a share, below analyst forecasts of 72 cents a share. The company cut its 2005 earnings estimate to "closer to" $2.30 a share from $2.40. For the second-quarter earnings from continuing operations declined to $274 million, or 64 cents a share, from $294 million, or 65 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter, but topped the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 61 cents a share. Sales for the period climbed 9% to $3.3 billion. See full story. Opnet Technologies Inc. OPNT, +0.68% slid 5.1% after it reported late Monday first-quarter revenue of $16.5 million, down from $16.8 million in the year-earlier period, and below the company's prior forecast of $16.6 million to $17.5 million. The loss for the quarter was $454,000, or 2 cents a share, vs. earnings of $2 million, or 10 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and wider than analyst forecasts for a loss of a penny a share. Oriental Financial Group OFG, -2.34% fell 8.4% after the company reported late Monday fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that fell below expectations. The Puerto Rico-based financial services company said it earned $6.4 million, or 26 cents a share, down from $16.9 million, or 67 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 34 cents a share. The company the flattening yield curve narrowed interest spreads, while continued interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve led to higher interest costs. Interest income rose 15% to $48.9 million, while interest expenses grew 49% to $29.6 million. Non-interest income fell 49% to $6.4 million. StarTek Inc SRT, -0.41% shed 13.7% after the company said second-quarter earnings fell to $2.6 million, or 18 cents a share, from $6.5 million, or 44 cents a share, a year ago. Analysts had been expecting average earnings of 24 cents a share from the business process outsourcing company. Revenue dropped 15.9% to $53.2 million following a downturn in supply chain management services and a shift in the company's revenue mix. Tyco International Ltd. TYC, +74.50% lost 9.6% after it said fiscal fourth-quarter earnings, excluding non-recurring items, were expected to be 45 to 47 cents a share, below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 52 cents a share. For its fiscal third quarter, the diversified industrial conglomerate reported earnings of $1.19 billion, or 56 cents a share, up from $923 million, or 43 cents, in the year-earlier period. Excluding special items, earnings would have been 50 cents a share, topping analyst forecasts of 49 cents. Revenue rose $10.56 billion from $10.23 billion, but missed analyst projections of $10.67 billion. See full story. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AAON Inc. shares AAON, +1.04% took an 11% dive after the air conditioner and heating equipment maker reported second-quarter earnings of $3.1 million, or 24 cents a share, up from $1.6 million, or 12 cents a share in the year-earlier period, but below analyst forecasts of 30 cents a share, according to an average of 2 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 5.5% to $45.4 million, below one analyst's forecast of $49.5 million. The stock was last down $2.16 at $17.02.
title: AAON dives as earns growth misses expectations

content: Waste Industries Q3 earnings beats Wall Street (11:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Waste Industries WWIN, +0.00% said late Tuesday that third-quarter earnings were $3.4 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $3.1 million, or 23 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $75.2 million vs. $70.8 million a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for third-quarter earnings of 24 cents a share. Medicines Co expects 2004 sales $139M-$145M (9:36 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- The Medicines Co. MDCO, -0.84% said late Tuesday it expects 2004 sales of $139 million to $145 million, rather than the forecast of $139 million to $141 million issued on the company's third-quarter conference call earlier in the day. The adjustment stems from the recognition of European revenue in the third quarter, which was calculated at a contracted initial price. The Medicines Co. said it may adjust those sales in the fourth quarter based on the end user price. SL Green Q3 FFO, EPS rise (8:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- SL Green Realty Corp. SLG, -0.36% said late Tuesday that its third-quarter net income rose to $20.3 million, or 49 cents a share, from $19.4 million, or 59 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Funds from operations rose to $40.7 million, or 94 cents a share, from $33.9 million, or 87 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting funds from operations of 95 cents a share. Matria Healthcare Q3 earns rise on 20% sales increase (7:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Matria Healthcare MATR, -2.33% posted higher third-quarter earnings late Tuesday, as sales rose 20 percent. The Marietta, Ga.-based provider of disease management services and products said it made $3.3 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $2.4 million, or 23 cents a share, last year. Revenue came in at $76 million vs. $63.1 million. Matria said it expects earnings from continuing operations to come in betweeen 34 cents and 36 cents a share in the fourth quarter, on sales ranging from $74 million to $78 million. The earnings forecast excludes an accounting change for the treatment of contingently convertible debt securities. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of 35 cents for the period. Teradyne swings to Q3 profit, sees Q4 below targets (7:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Teradyne Inc. TER, +1.96% said late Tuesday that it swung to a profit in the third quarter, as sales rose despite a drop in customer orders. The semiconductor equipment maker said it made $41.1 million, or 21 cents a share, on sales of $457.8 million. Last year, Teradyne posted a loss of $53.5 million, or 28 cents a share, on sales of $329.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Teradyne said it expects to report earnings per share of breakeven to 4 cents a share on revenue between $360 million and $380 million in the fourth quarter. Analysts are looking for earnings of 16 cents a share on revenue of $427 million, according to Thomson First Call. Palm Harbor Q2 loss 10c vs 2c (7:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Palm Harbor Homes Inc. PHHM said late Tuesday that its second-quarter net loss was $2.2 million, or 10 cents per share, vs $515,000, or 2 cents a share, a year ago. Net sales totaled $150.5 million compared with $148.5 million. The marketer and builder of manufactured homes said net sales were weaker than expected due to hurricane activity on the East Coast. Churchill Downs swings to Q3 loss on charges (7:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Churchill Downs Inc. CHDN, +0.83% late Tuesday said it had a third-quarter loss of $3.8 million, or 29 cents a share, including impairment charges at its Ellis Park racetrack totaling $6.2 million, or 34 cents a share. In the year-ago period, the horse racing venue operator reported a profit of $7.9 million, or 59 cents a share. Revenue fell 1.4 percent to $122.2 million. CoStar Q3 posts higher earnings on new customer orders (6:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- CoStar Group CSGP, +1.87% said Tuesday after the bell that third-quarter earnings were $2.4 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with $281,000, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier. The real estate services company said third-quarter pro forma earnings were $4 million, or 21 cents a share, vs. $2.1 million, or 13 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $28.6 million vs. $24.1 million a year earlier. The company said for the fourth quarter it expects net earnings of 14 cents a share and revenue to grow in the range of 3.5 percent to 4 percent, from the previous quarter. Pro forma earnings for the fourth quarter will be about 22 cents a share, CoStar said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for fourth-quarter earnings of 21 cents a share. For 2004 the company said it is looking for net earnings of 44 cents a share and pro forma earnings of 78 cents a share. Analysts are looking for 2004 earnings of 76 cents a share. IMCO Recycling restates '03 results (6:12 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- IMCO Recycling Inc. IMR, +5.88% late Tuesday said it is restating its 2003 financial statements to reflect a change in accounting for its acquisition of full ownership of its German subsidiary, VAW-IMCO Guss und Recycling GmbH, during that year. The company's restated 2003 net loss is $812,000, or 6 cents a share. Previously, IMCO had said it earned $5 million, or 33 cents a share. The company says it will file its restated 2003 financials in an amendment to its Form 10-K, and that the restatements should not impact its proposed merger with Commonwealth Industries CMIN Wausau Paper Q3 earns increase 36% (5:58 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Wausau Paper WPP, -0.21% late Tuesday reported third-quarter earnings of $8.1 million, or 16 cents a share, compared with $6 million, or 12 cents a share, a year ago. Sales were $262.4 million, up from $249.5 million a year ago. The company sees fourth-quarter earnings in-line with last year's earnings of 10 cents a share, excluding a charge of 2 cents a share related to costs to start up a paper facility in Brainerd, Minn., which it purchased in a deal earlier this month. UnionBanCal Q3 earnings miss Wall Street (5:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- UnionBanCal UB said late Tuesday its third-quarter earnings were $163.4 million, or $1.09 a share, vs. $155 million, or $1.02 a share, a year ago. The bank holding company said revenue for the quarter was $629.1 million compared with $603.2 million a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for third-quarter earnings of $1.11 a share on revenue of $627 million. Net interest income for the third-quarter was $413.1 million, compared with $401.7 million a year ago. The company said it expects fourth-quarter earnings to be between $1.11 a share and $1.15 a share. Analysts are expecting fourth-quarter earnings of $1.13 a share. Advance Auto Parts says Q3 earns 68c (5:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Advance Auto Parts AAP, +2.22% late Tuesday said that its third-quarter earnings came to 68 cents a share, according to preliminary figures. For the fourth quarter, the company said it expects to earn 42 cents to 46 cents a share. MKS Instruments shares fall on Q4 forecast (5:35 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of MKS Instruments MKSI, +3.86% fell more than 5 percent late Tuesday after forecasting fourth-quarter results below analyst expectations. The maker of process control equipment for the chip industry forecast net earnings of 2 cents to 9 cents a share and pro forma earnings of 9 cents to 16 cents a share, citing softening orders from semiconductor clients. MKS Instruments forecast sales declining 10 percent to 18 percent from the third quarter to $115 million to $125 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call were expecting fourth-quarter earnings of 22 cents a share on sales of $129 million. The company also reported third-quarter earnings of $12.2 million, or 22 cents a share. Last year, it lost $5.6 million, or 11 cents a share. On a pro forma basis, earnings were $15.8 million, or 29 cents a share. AMCC sees Q3 sales flat vs. Q2 (5:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Applied Micro Circuits AMCC sees fiscal third-quarter sales about flat with the $61.1 million reported in the second quarter, according to Chief Operating Officer Tom Tullie during a conference call. Tullie predicted gross margins of 60 to 62 percent Helmerich & Payne sees Q4 loss after rig charge (5:27 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Helmerich & Payne on Tuesday said it expects to report a fourth-quarter loss because of a $48 million to $53 million, or 58 cent to 65 cent a share, charge tied to the company's Gulf of Mexico offshore rigs. Analysts had expected a per-share profit of 14 cents, according to Thomson First Call. FLYi posts Sept. load factor of 48% (5:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- FLYi Inc. FLYI late Tuesday reported September traffic of 175,345 with a load factor of 48 percent. Traffic for the third quarter was 563,471, with a load factor of 53.8 percent. FLYi's Independence Air unit had September traffic of 139,279 and a load factor of 44.4 percent. Scientific Learning delays Q3 earnings release (5:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Scientific Learning SCIL, +1.67% late Tuesday said it is delaying the release of its third-quarter results so that it can resolve an accounting issue. The provider of reading software for children says it now realizes that certain revenue may have to be recognized ratably over a longer period than had been previously anticipated. As a result, the company may be required to restate certain previously reported financial results. Scientific Learning emphasized that the accounting issues it faces are technical, and do not involve "suggestions of improprieties or conduct." The company added that third-quarter sales were "well below the estimated range," due to hurricanes and flooding in the Southeast region of the U.S. and school superintendent changes in one of its key states. Sovereign Bancorp Q3 earns falls, miss Wall Street (5:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Sovereign Bancorp SOV, +12.26% said after the bell Tuesday that third-quarter net income was $82.5 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with $109.2 million, or 37 cents a share a year ago. Earnings include $60.8 million in after-tax charges. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for third-quarter earnings 42 cents a share. Sovereign reported third-quarter net interest income was $363 million vs. $287.3 million a year ago. Sovereign said it is comfortable with mangement's 2004 earnings outlook in the range of $1.85 and $1.90 a share, excluding charges. Analysts are expecting 2004 earnings of $1.67 a share. The company said it is also comfortable with analysts' outlook for 2005 earnings in the range of $1.91 a share. Silicon Graphics cuts losses despite sales drop (5:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Silicon Graphics Inc. trimmed losses for its first fiscal quarter despite a 14-percent drop in revenue compared to the same period last year. The maker of high-end workstations and storage hardware SGI, +3.17% reported a net loss of $28 million, or 11 cents per share, compared to a loss of $48 million, or 23 cents per share, in last year's first quarter. Analysts expected a loss of 5 cents per share. Revenue for the period was $174.6 million compared to $202.2 million last year. LodgeNet Entertainment narrows loss in Q3 (5:06 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- LodgeNet Entertainment LNET late Tuesday reported a third-quarter loss of $3.5 million, or 20 cents per share, narrower than its loss of $5.4 million, or 43 cents per share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $72 million, compared with $68 million in 2003. LodgeNet expects to report a loss of $20.5 million to $19 million, or $1.34 to $1.24 a share, for 2004, on revenue of $265 million to $268 million. Dover posts 57% rise in Q3 earns; rev up 29% (5:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- New York-based diversified industrial manufacturer Dover Corp. DOV, +2.09% on Tuesday posted a third-quarter profit of $116.9 million, or 58 cents a share, on $1.44 billion in revenue, up from $75.2 million, or 37 cents a share, on sales of $1.12 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected a profit of 56 cents a share on sales of $1.39 billion. Medicines Co. swings to profit in Q3 (4:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- The Medicines Co. MDCO, -0.84% late Tuesday reported third-quarter earnings of $5.3 million, or 11 cents per share. Last year the company posted a loss of $6.2 million, or 13 cents per share. Revenue for the quarter was $37.7 million, compared with $21.2 million in 2003. The company raised the lower end of its earnings outlook for 2004 to a range of $15 million to $19 million, up from $12 million to $19 million, with a revenue forecast of $139 million to $141 million, up from its previous estimate of $134 million to $139 million. Armor Holdings 3Q revenue, profit surges (4:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Armor Holdings, Inc. AH, +3.65% reported late Tuesday third-quarter net income of $23.9 million, or 70 cents per share, vs. the year-ago level of $6.1 million, or 22 cents per share. Excluding 11 cents in charges, the company said it earned 81 cents a share. Analysts, according to Thomson First Call, forecast an estimate of 76 cents a share. Revenue rose 183 percent to $256.8 million, up from $90.9 million. AT&T Wireless earnings decline (4:43 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- AT&T Wireless AWE, +5.26% on Tuesday said second-quarter profit fell because of lower sales and higher expenses stemming from attempts to keep customers from leaving.
