The Baltimore, Md.-based bank said the results translated to 71 cents a share, up 13 percent from 63 cents a share last year. The results fell short of the average analyst estimate of 74 cents a share, as measured by Thomson First Call. Shares closed up 18 cents to $49.09. United Bankshares Q3 earns match expectations (8:01 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- United Bankshares UBSI, +0.71% reported third-quarter earnings of $24.5 million, or 56 cents a share, up from $22.9 million, or 55 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Net interest income increased 22 percent to $52.2 million and non-interest income rose 5.8 percent to $13.9 million. The community and mortgage banking services company's stock closed Monday down 8 cents at $35.54. Taser Q3 earnings at 21c per share, above estimates (7:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Taser International TASR reported net income Tuesday of $6.1 million, or 21 cents per share, compared to $1.08 million, or 6 cents per share in the same period in 2003. A Thomson First Call survey of analysts produced a consensus estimate of 15 cents per share. Sales rose to $18.9 million in the quarter from $6.1 million in the third quarter of 2003. Shares of the stun gun maker rose 6 percent in pre-open trading on Instinet to $40.49 Monday. Bancorpsouth Inc. reports lower Q3 profit (7:56 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Bancorpsouth BXS, +0.47% reported third-quarter net income of $27.6 million, or 36 cents per share vs. $33.9 million, or 43 cents per share last year. The latest quarter includes a non-cash charge of 2 cents per share for impairment of mortgage servicing assets. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 37 cents per share for Bancorpsouth. Shares of Bancorpsouth Inc. fell 24 cents to $23.87 on Monday. AmSouth reports Q3 net income of $119 mln, down 24% (7:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- AmSouth Bancorp ASO, -3.41% on Tuesday reported third quarter net income fell to $119 million, or 33 cents a share, from $157 million, or 45 cents a share, the same period last year. The Birmingham, Ala.-based bank said it took a $54 million charge for fees during the quarter related to a regulatory settlement. Without the charge, AmSouth earned 48 cents a share. The results beat the average analyst estimate of 47 cents a share, as measured by Thomson First Call. Safeco reports wider Q3 loss (7:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Safeco SAFC reported a third-quarter loss of $101.1 million, or 76 cents a share, vs. a loss of 21 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Earnings excluding discontinued operations, losses on debt repurchases and gains from investments were $51.8 million. Revenue from ongoing operations was $1.57 billion vs. last year's $1.38 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting revenue of $1.5 billion, on average. The property and casualty insurance company's stock closed Monday up 21 cents at $45.75. Greene County Bancshares Q3 EPS 42c vs 38c (7:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Greene County Bancshares, Inc. GCBS reported third-quarter earnings of $3.2 million, or 42 cents per share, up from earnings of $2.6 million, or 38 cents, in the year earlier period. The Greeneville, Tenn., bank said net interest income, after provision for loan losses, rose 33 percent to $11.4 million. Shares of Greene County Bancshares closed Monday down 4 cents at $23.81. Tandy Brands Accessories Q1 net 43c vs 45c (7:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Tandy Brands Accessories TBAC Tuesday said its first-quarter net income was $2.8 million, or 43 cents per share, compared to net income of $2.8 million, or 45 cents a year earlier. The Thomson First Call estimate was for EPS of 46 cents. Net sales for the maker of belts and wallets fell to $60.5 million from $64.2 million. The share Monday increased 29 cents to $14.74. First Cash Q3 net income rises (7:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- First Cash Financial Services FCFS, +2.01% reported third-quarter net income of $5.2 million, or 31 cents per share, up from $4 million, or 25 cents per share last year. The Arlington, Texas financial firm was expected to earn 31 cents per share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The company forecasted fourth-quarter earnings of 34-36 cents per share, vs the Wall Street estimate of 36 cents. Shares of First Cash rose 11 cents to $21.86 on Monday. Ameritrade Q4 earns tops ests., 2005 to also beat (7:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Ameritrade Holding Corp. AMTD, +3.49% reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $57.2 million, or 14 cents a share, up from $55.1 million, or 13 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 11 cents a share. Revenue fell 5 percent to $186.8 million, as a 24 percent decline in commissions and clearing fees offset a 57 percent rise in interest revenue, vs. analyst forecasts of $187.5 million. Looking ahead, the discount broker expects to earn 72 to 89 cents a share in fiscal 2005, above analyst projections of 70 cents. The stock closed Monday up 2 cents at $11.55. Pain Therapeutics Q3 EPS: 26c; maintains 2004 outlook (7:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Pain Therapeutics Inc. PTIE, +8.74% reported a third-quarter loss of $9.2 million, or 26 cents per share, compared to a loss of $6 million, or 21 cents, in the the year earlier period. The average analyst estimate as polled by Thomson First Call is for a loss of 27 cents per share. The South San Francisco biopharmaceutical company maintained its outlook for 2004 and said research and development costs in the third quarter rose 57 percent to $8.5 million. Shares of Pain Therapeutics closed Monday up 11 cents at $6.78. DSP Group Q3 earns tops estimates, but revenue misses (7:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- DSP Group DSPG, +2.16% reported third-quarter earnings of $20.4 million, or 69 cents a share, up from $9.6 million, or 32 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Earnings excluding the capital and tax-related gains from the sale of assets were 33 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 29 cents. Revenue fell 2 percent to $46.2 million, below analyst forecasts of $48.2 million, due to demand and inventory issues across different product lines. The chipmaker said it increased its stock repurchase program by 2.5 million shares. The stock closed Monday down a penny at $19.40. Air conditioner maker AAON Q3 falls, misses forecasts (7:30 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Air conditioning and heating equipment maker AAON Inc. AAON, +1.04% said third quarter earnings fell to $1.52 million, or 12 cents a share, from $3.6 million, or 27 cents a share, on rising material costs and lack of margin improvement from its product price increases. Analysts had forecasted earnings of 14 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. The company added that second half earnings will "only approximate" first half earnings on the material cost rises. Sales rose 16.4 percent to $47 million in the quarter. Kelly Services Q3 EPS top forecasts but lowers outlook (7:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Kelly Services KELYA, +0.90% posted third-quarter earnings of $7.4 million, or 21 cents a share, on revenue of $1.245 billion, compared to $1.5 million, or 4 cents a share, on revenue of $1.097 billion a year ago. Earnings were a penny above the 20 cents a share average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, however, the provider of temporary staffing services said it expects fourth quarter earnings to range from 19 to 24 cents a share and full year earnings in a range of 57 to 62 cents a share. The First Call average forecasts are for earnings of 25 cents a share for the fourth quarter and 63 cents a share for the year. Journal Comm. Q3 earns tops ests., Q4 rev. to miss (7:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Journal Communications JRN, +0.00% reported third-quarter earnings of $19.2 million, or 25 cents a share, up from $18.6 million, or 24 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 24 cents a share. Revenue rose 2.7 percent to $204.4 million from $199.1 million, amid advertising revenue growth in its TV and radio stations and in its daily newspapers, but was just shy of analyst forecasts of $207.1 million. For the fourth quarter, the media company expects revenue of $205 million to $210 million, below analyst projections of $215 million, and net earnings of $20 million to $23 million. The stock closed Monday up 13 cents at $16.79. Arbitron Q3 net beats Street view; revenues miss (7:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Arbitron Inc ARB, +0.00% posted Tuesday third quarter net income of $24.2 million, or 77 cents per share, compared with $17 million, or 55 cents per share in the same quarter a year ago. Revenue for the quarter rose 8.8 percent to $82 million from $75.3 million. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 61 cents on revenue of $83.4 million. The stock was down 0.1 percent, at $36.87 at the close of trading Monday. Cache Q3 loss 3c vs net 4c (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Women's clothing retailer Cache CACH, +200.00% Tuesday reported a third-quarter net loss of $521,000, or 3 cents per share, contrasting with net income of $614,000, or 4 cents a year earlier. The Thomson First Call analysts consensus was for a quarterly loss of 4 cents per share. Net sales increased 4.4 percent to $49.4 million from $47.3 million, while same-store sales declined 2 percent. First Call predicted quarterly sales of $49.85 million. On Monday the stock rose 1 cent to $14.86. EMC meets Q3 EPS estimate, sees revenues jump (7:21 AM ET) EMC Corp. EMC, +9.92% reported third quarter revenues, excluding acquisitions, up 19 percent. Total revenues, including acquisitions rose more than a third to $2.03 billion versus $1.51 billion in the third quarter last year. The data storage company delivered earnings per share of 9 cents, in line with analyst estimates. It said it expected fourth quarter EPS of 11 cents to 12 cents, also in line with forecasts, along with revenues of $2.23 billion and $2.27 billion. Net income for the third quarter was $218 million, up from $159 million. West Pharmaceutical Services up '04 sales view (7:21 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- West Pharmaceutical Services WST, +2.07% upped its 2004 sales forecast and reiterated 2004 earnings outlook after it said third quarter earnings were $4.3 million, or 14 cents a share, vs. $4.1 million a year ago and 14 cents EPS on a post-split basis. Third quarter sales rose 12.6 percent to $135.3 million, and it sees fourth quarter sales rising 8 percent to 10 percent before currency effects. Manpower Q3 earns tops expectations, Q4 to also beat (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Manpower MAN, +2.35% reported third-quarter earnings of $83.4 million, or 89 cents a share, up from $43.8 million, or 56 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose 22 percent to $3.9 billion, boosted by strength in its financial services unit. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 66 cents a share and revenue of $3.86 billion, on average. The employment services company expects to earn 69 to 73 cents a share in the fourth quarter vs. analyst forecasts of 66 cents. The stock closed Monday unchanged at $41.99. Sprint adj Q3 net beats estimates; raises 2004 outlook (7:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Sprint FON, +5.56% said Tuesday it was raising its 2004 outlook on a stronger operating performance after the telecom operator posted adjusted third quarter earnings ahead of analyst estimates. The Overland Park, Kansas-based company posted a net loss of $1.32 per share which includes a $1.53 per share loss associtated with its decision to end its Long Distance operations. Excluding this charge, the company earned 24 cents share compared with 19 cents a share in the same period a year ago. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 14 cents a share. Revenues for the quarter were $6.99 billion compared with $6.71 billion. Looking ahead, Sprint said it now expects to earn between 84 cents and 86 cents per share in 2004 compared with a prior estimate of 74 cents to 78 cents per share. Revenue is now expected to grow between 4 percent and 5 percent versus a previous outlook of 3 percent to 4 percent. The stock was down 0.4 percent at $20.60 at the close of trading Monday. Altria Q3 earns top estimates, narrows Q4 outlook (7:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Altria Group MO, -0.21% reported third-quarter earnings of $2.65 billion, or $1.29 a share, up from $2.49 billion, or $1.22 a share in the same period a year ago. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of $1.25 a share, on average. Sales rose 8.5 percent to $22.7 billion from $20.9 billion, amid a 1.5 percent rise in domestic tobacco sales and 16 percent growth in international tobacco sales. The tobacco and food company narrowed its 2004 earnings forecast to $4.55 to $4.60 a share from $4.50 to $4.60 a share. The stock, a component of the Dow industrials, closed Monday up 4 cents at $47.40. Reckitt Benckiser rallies after Q3, share buyback plan (7:12 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Lysol maker Reckitt Benckiser(UK:RB)jumped 5.6 percent in London after it upped its earnings and sales forecasts for 2004 after posting a 23 percent rise in profits to 151 million pounds, as sales rose 1 percent to 976 million pounds. It said its 2004 forecast was lifted for both sales and earnings, with Reckitt now seeing sales rise by around 9 percent instead of 7 percent and earnings rising 22 percent vs. 18 percent at constant exchange rates, with both falling by 6 percent if current rates remain the same. It said it will start a 300 million pound share buyback for the year ending in the third quarter 2005. Diamond Offshore Q3 falls short of forecasts (7:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Diamond Offshore Drilling DO, +2.95% said it earned $2.9 million, or 2 cents a share, on revenue of $208.2 million, shy of the 4 cents a share average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. A year ago, the deep water drilling company posted a loss of $11.5 million, or 9 cents a share, on revenue of $183.9 million. The company said results in the current quarter were negatively impacted by 4 cents a share for items related to Hurricane Ivan and 2 cents a share for downtime for equipment repairs as well as other items that negatively impacted net income by a total of 2 cents a share. Radio Shack Q3 net 43c vs 34c (7:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Radio Shack RSH, -0.07% Tuesday reported third-quarter net income of $69.7 million or 43 cents per share, compared to $57.1 million or 34 cents a year earlier. The Thomson First Call analysts consensus was for third-quarter earnings per share of 39 cents. Third quarter 2004 same-store sales were up 5% compared to the prior year. Quarterly revenue was $1.101 billion, up slightly from 1.063 billion a year before; the First Call projection was for $1.09 billion. On Monday Radio Shack stock rose 38 cents to $29.60. Ford Motor Q3 results top estimates, ups 2004 outlook (7:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Ford Motor F, +2.03% reported third-quarter earnings of $266 million, or 15 cents a share, vs. a loss of $25 million, or a penny a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings from continuing operations were 28 cents a share. Revenue rose to $39 billion from $36.7 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 14 cents a share and revenue of $31.2 billion. The automaker raised its 2004 earnings forecast to $2 to $2.05 a share from $1.90 to $2 a share due to the strong performance of its financial services business. The stock closed Monday up 14 cents at $13.39. Comerica Q3 earns rise, top expectations (6:56 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Comerica CMA, +1.76% reported third-quarter earnings of $196 million, or $1.13 a share, up from $157 million, or 89 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $1.05 a share. Net interest income declined 3 percent to $451 million and non-interest income fell 6.8 percent to $206 million. The financial services company's stock closed Monday up 69 cents at $63.02. Safeway Q3 earns decline, sales miss estimates (6:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Safeway SWY, +1.82% reported third-quarter earnings of $159.2 million, or 35 cents a share, down from $202.5 million, or 45 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Earnings were reduced by about 10 cents a share by the labor strike in Southern California and by 3 cents a share by the contribution to health plans. In addition, there was a 7-cents-a-share benefit from the resolution of tax issues. Sales were flat at $8.3 billion, missing the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $8.49 billion. For 2004, the grocery store chain said earnings were tracking at the low end of prior forecasts. The stock closed Monday up a penny at $18.78. Ethan Allen tops Q1 estimates by a penny (6:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Ethan Allen Interiors ETH, -1.08% said it earned $18.9 million, or 51 cents a share in the first quarter to end September, against 50 cents a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 50 cents a share. Sales rose 3.4 percent to $230.2 million from $222.8 million. The First Call estimate was for sales of $228 million. Same-store sales rose 4.9 percent from a year ago. The company said it is confident it can grow sales at least 5 percent and earnings at least 8 percent in fiscal 2005, in line with, or above, current consensus estimates. Shares closed Monday down 12 cents at $33.80. Fargo Elec. Q3 EPS fall to 18c from 19c, sales rise (6:25 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Identification card maker Fargo Electronics Inc. FRGO on Tuesday said that third-quarter earnings fell to $2.3 million, or 18 cents per share, compared with $2.5 million, or 19 cents per share, in the year-earlier period. The results beat the average analyst forecast compiled by Thomson First Call of 15 cents per share. Sales rose to $19.6 million from $17 million a year ago. Fargo said it sees fourth-quarter 2004 earnings-per-share in the range of 14 cents to 18 cents and full year EPS of 57 cents to 61 cents. Continental Air: 'Significant losses' possible in 2005 (6:17 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Despite a cost-cutting effort outlined in September, carrier Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% said it expects a "significant loss for 2004, and unless the current environment improves, expects to record a significant loss in 2005 as well." The airline posted a $16 million net loss or 24 cents a share in the third quarter, reflecting a charge to retire leased aircraft. It booked a $15 million mark-to-market gain relating to the carrier's Orbitz holdings. " "With oil at stratospheric prices and the government siphoning off more than $1 billion annually in fees and non-income related taxes, it's amazing that we were able to produce these modest results for the quarter," said CEO and Chair Gordon Bethune in a statement. Passenger revenue for the quarter was rose 8.7 percent to $2.4 billion on increased revenue from international flights and more regional flying. Corn Products lifts low end '04 view, tops on Q3 (5:45 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Corn Products International CPO, +0.00% lifted the low end of its 2004 forecast to a 23 percent net profit rise vs. a 21 percent rise, after topping earnings estimates in the third quarter with a $24 million, or 64 cents a share, profit vs. $20 million, or 55 cents a share a year ago. Analysts had anticipated third quarter EPS of 59 cents a share. Sales rose to $587 million from $541 million a year ago. SKF tops on Q3 forecast, Q4 to be lifted by Asia, LatAm (5:20 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Swedish ball-bearings group SKF(SE:000010822)said third quarter pre-tax income rose to SEK1.1 billion from SEK697 million, beating analyst forecasts, as sales rose 14.1 percent to SEK11.1 billion, with 9.6 percent of that rise coming from higher volumes. SKF said the market demand is expected to continue to be higher in Europe and North America and significantly higher in Asia and Latin America, while the manufacturing level will be unchanged from the third quarter. Eurotunnel Q3 op. revs fall due to fewer cars, coaches (2:51 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Eurotunnel(UK:ETL), operator of the Channel Tunnel crossing between France and the U.K., said its results for the third quarter were "obviously not satisfactory," confirming decision to begin to review the business in July. Total operating revenue fell 4 percent to 140.1 million pounds as fewer cars and trucks passed through the tunnel. Coach traffic fell 13 percent and car traffic fell 5 percent. Eurotunnel's market share fell, it said, due to over-capacity and "intense" price competition. U.K. chip designer ARM Q3 tops forecasts (2:40 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. chip designer ARM Holdings ARMHY (UK:ARM)said Tuesday that third quarter EPS rose to 5 cents per ADS from 2.3 cents in the year-ago period, as revenue rose to $70.1 million from $50.5 million. Its pre-tax income of 13.3 million pounds topped estimates of 11.1 million pounds, AFX News said. ARM said it is "well-positioned" to grow 2004 revenue by 30 percent. Online Egg bank: UK pre-tax profit GBP 53 mln since Jan (2:34 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. online bank Egg(UK:EGG), majority owned by U.K. insurer Prudential PUK, -1.01% (UK:PRU), posted a 103 million pound loss since the start of the year, reflecting a provision 113 million to exit the French market. In its UK business, Egg said it saw an operating profit of 53 million pounds, down from 57 million pounds in the year-ago period. "Our withdrawal from the French market is progressing and as we announced earlier this month we have received approaches for the consumer credit, savings and brokerage businesses which, if concluded, would result in the redeployment of up to 140 people," it said. Egg expects the 3 million pounds in costs in the disposal of its funds supermarket, Egg Invest, to Fidelity FundsNetwork. Akzo Nobel: Q3 earns up, FY net income in line with '03 (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Dutch pharmaceutical giant Akzo Nobel AKZOY, -1.20% (NL:00913)said net income for the third quarter rose 20 percent, excluding nonrecurring items worth 213 million euros. Total net income amounted to 521 million euros, due to a net nonrecurring gain of 308 million euros. Pharmaceutical sales were down 9 percent due to lower volumes at Organon and Diosynth and currencies. It said Organon is facing a major decline in Remeron sales due to generic competition. Looking ahead, it said: "We are facing steeply increasing raw material and energy prices and there are increasing uncertainties due to softening macroeconomic conditions." It did not expect to be able to match last year's "very strong" fourth quarter. It says it expects it now expects net income for the year, excluding nonrecurring items, will be around 2003 level. Sainsbury lowers dividend, sees 2H pre-tax flat on 1H (2:22 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. supermarkets group J. Sainsbury(UK:SBRY)expects underlying pre-tax profit for the first half year from between 125 million to 135 million pounds, and it sees the second half year not "significantly different from the first half" as it pursues a "sales led profit recovery." The group also sees a decline in its dividend for the year to 7.8 pence a share in order to invest 135 million pounds into the business. Same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, rose 1.8 percent in the 16 weeks to Oct. 9. Same-store sales showed a 1.1 percent decline excluding petrol sales. Total sales grew 4.4 percent. "We have continued to invest in the customer offer, particularly pricing, and as a result in-store deflation in the quarter was 1.1 percent," the group said. First-half profit was impacted by margin investment, it said. Reuters Q3 sales down 13%, sees Q4 sub down 3% (2:17 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Reuters Group(UK:RTR) RTRSY the FTSE 100 news and financial data provider, expects underlying revenue from subscriptions - its core business - to drop by close to 5.5 percent for the year. Reuters said third quarter revenue dropped 13 percent on an actual basis to 570 million pounds. Revenue was down 5 percent on an underlying basis reflecting currency movements while recurring revenue - or subscriptions - dropped 4.4 percent to 528 million pounds. The decline in recurring revenue topped Reuters own forecast for a 5 percent decline. Reuter's full year outlook for a sales decline implies a 3 percent decline in core revenue for the fourth quarter. "Reuters made good progress towards recovery this quarter. Despite uncertain market conditions, gross sales outpaced cancellations during the quarter for the first time since the first quarter of 2001," the company said. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Air conditioning and heating equipment maker AAON Inc. AAON, +1.04% said third quarter earnings fell to $1.52 million, or 12 cents a share, from $3.6 million, or 27 cents a share, on rising material costs and lack of margin improvement from its product price increases. Analysts had forecasted earnings of 14 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. The company added that second half earnings will "only approximate" first half earnings on the material cost rises. Sales rose 16.4 percent to $47 million in the quarter.
title: Air conditioner maker AAON Q3 falls, misses forecasts

content: Juniper Networks lifts Q3 earnings outlook (5:56 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (CBS.MW) -- Juniper Networks JNPR, +1.16% expects in its third quarter to earn 11 cents a share before items on sales of $366 million to $370 million, Chief Financial Officer Marcel Gani said during a conference call Tuesday. That's higher than Wall Street analysts currently expect. The average analyst estimate currently calls for earnings of 10 cents a share on sales of $344.6 million, according to a Thomson First Call survey. For the entire second half, the company puts earnings before items at 23 cents to 24 cents a share on sales of $760 million to $770 million. The company earlier blew past estimates with its second-quarter results. The shares posted sharp gains in the extended-hours session, after closing the regular session lower by 1.3 percent at $22. Raymond James reports $29 mil. in 3Q net income, up 26% (4:54 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Raymond James reported net income of $29.6 million for the third quarter, up 26 percent from the same period last year, the company said Tuesday. The earnings translated to 40 cents a share, up from 32 cents in the same period a year ago. Revenue was $440 million, up from $377 million from the fiscal third quarter of 2003. Analysts were expecting a 48 cents a share in earnings, according to Thomson First Call. Shares of the St. Petersburgh, Fla.-based brokerage RJF, +2.17% closed down 19 cents to $24.61. CORRECT: Juniper Networks posts Q2 net loss, sales soar (4:23 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (CBS.MW) -- Juniper Networks JNPR, +1.16% on Tuesday said it lost $12.6 million, or 2 cents a share, in the second quarter, compared to a year-ago profit of $13.6 million, or 3 cents a share. Sales for the period jumped to $306.9 million from $165.1 million. Excluding items, earnings rose to $42.7 million, or 8 cents a share, from $10.3 million, or 3 cents a share, a year ago. The earnings exceeded Wall Street expectations. Analysts had, on average, expected the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based networking company to report earnings of 4 cents on sales of $275.15 million, according to a Thomson First Call survey. Shares of Juniper closed lower by 1.3 percent at $22 ahead of the earnings report. (Corrects comparison to Wall Street expectations.) Intel Q2 earns 27c, sales $8.05 bln (4:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Intel INTC, +5.00% reported second-quarter sales of $8.05 billion, within its targeted range but slightly below the $8.1 billion that most analysts expected. The chipmaker's net income totaled 27 cents a share, matching the consensus target. Intel predicted third-quarter sales between $8.6 billion and $9.2 billion. Intevac slumps on Q3 earnings, revenue outlook (4:14 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Intevac IVAC, +2.99% ended sharply lower Tuesday after the company's third quarter earnings outlook came in well below current analyst expectations. In a conference call outlining its second quarter results, the maker of sensitive electro-optical devices and systems said it expects earnings in the third quarter in a range of breakeven to 5 cents a share. This compares with the Thomson First Call average estimate of 29 cents a share. Intevac said its forecast is primarily the result of lower projected gross margins on the first production line of its 200 Lean disk product offering. Revenue for the quarter is expected to come in between $24 million to $27 million against a current First Call average estimate of $33.8 million. For 2004, Intevac said it is projecting revenues in the range of 70 million to 75 million. Meanwhile, the Santa Clara, California-based company reported second quarter net income of $781,000, or 4 cents a share, a penny ahead of analyst expectations. This compares with a net loss of $.48 million, or 39 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. Intevac was the biggest percentage decliner on the Nasdaq, ending the session, down $3.18, or 43.3 percent, at $4.17. Manatron soars 16% on sharp rise in fiscal Q4 net (2:40 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Manatron MANA soared 16 percent to $9.65 after the computer software company posted a 82 percent rise in fiscal fourth quarter net income and a 57 percent jump in software licences fees. The company, which makes government revenue mananagement software products, reported net income of $989,000, or 23 cents a share versus $544,000, or 13 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. Revenues for the quarter rose to $11.3 million from $10.5 million. Meanwhile, software license fees and related service revenues climbed to $4.7 million from $3 million, buoyed by the completion of several property tax implementations in Florida, since the Manatron Tax product became available for general release in the state in March 2004. Intel the Nasdaq's most active ahead of Q2 results (2:40 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Intel INTC, +5.00% was the Nasdaq exchange's most-active stock with 46.3 million shares traded, but remained little changed ahead of the semiconductor sector bellwether's quarterly report. About 53.9 million shares change hands on a typical day. Intel is slated to reveal second-quarter results after the closing bell, with analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expecting earnings of 27 cents a share and revenue of $8.1 billion on average. The stock, a component of the Dow industrials, eased 11 cents to $26.13, and has lost 18 percent since the end of 2003. MDC Holdings rises 7% on forecast-beating Q2 net (2:13 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW)-- Shares of MDC Holdings MDC, +0.47% rose 7 percent to $65.80 Tuesday after the homebuilder reported second quarter earnings which far exceeded analyst estimates. After the bell Monday, the Denver, Colorado-based company posted net income of $82.6 million, or $2.43 per share compared with $42.7 million, or $1.30 per share in the same quarter in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of $1.93 per share. MDC attributed its strong quarterly performance to substantial increases in home sales revenues and home gross margins. Revenues for the quarter jumped 27 percent to $875 million compared with $689 million in the year-ago period, due mainly to a $23,000 increase in average selling prices on a record second quarter level of homes closed. CEO Larry Mizel said the company remains on track to post a "seventh consecutive year of record earnings in 2004." Kinder Morgan on track to meet 2004 financial goals (1:24 PM ET) DALLAS (CBS.MW) -- Kinder Morgan KMI, +1.69% a pipeline company, said it is on track to meet a previously announced earnings-per-share estimate of $3.71 in 2004. Kinder Morgan Energy Partners KMP, +0.63% -- Kinder Morgan owns the general partner interest -- is still expected to distribute $2.84 per unit in 2004. Both companies will report second-quarter earnings on July 21. Kinder Morgan's shares were off 28 cents at $59.75, while KMP's units were flat at $43.20. KLA-Tencor says June quarter orders come in flat (1:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- KLA-Tencor KLAC, +2.29% stated its bookings for the June quarter came in about flat sequentially, according to statements made at the start of an analyst meeting. The company declined to be specific or elaborate further ahead of its financial report on July 29. The chip-equipment company had expected an order decline of as much as 15 percent up to a possible increase of 10 percent. Prudential sees bigger FY04 loss for American Airlines (12:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Prudential Equity Group on Tuesday slashed its full-year 2004 earnings target for AMR Corp AMR, -4.53% parent of American Airlines. Prudential analyst Daniel Hemme cut his full-year loss estimate to $1.92 a share from 10 cents a share. "All in all, our near-term expectations have significantly diminished from the recent past," Hemme said in a research note. "We believe the demand, cost and competitive environment will unlikely produce favorable results for AMR for the remainder of 2004." He also lowered his stock price target to $11 from $17. Also Tuesday, Citigroup Smith Barney cut its stock rating on AMR to "hold." Shares of AMR fell 61 cents to $9.74 in midday trades. Oakley falls on profit warning, skepticism over 'Thump' (11:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Oakley OO tumbled 14 percent to $10.81 Tuesday after analysts downgraded the eyewear group following its profit warning overnight and uncertainty over likely demand for its new 'Thump' sunglass-MP3 player product. After the bell Monday, the company warned that an unexpected slowdown in second-quarter sales could bring 2004 profits in at the bottom end of its expectations. Wachovia Securities analyst Joseph Tecklits cut his rating on Oakley to "underperform" from "market perform." He also reduced his 2004 earnings estimate to 52 cents from 65 cents and his 2005 estimates to 66 cents from 76 cents. "We are cautious on the launch of the new Thump product in the holiday of 2004 period, and believe this product could fail in the marketplace," said Tecklits. Over at Wedbush Morgan, analyst Michael Pachter downgraded the company to "hold" from "buy," citing valuation, weakness in its core sunglass business and skepticism over Thump. Pachter cut his 2004 estimates by 8 cents to 60 cents per share and his 2005 estimates by 12 cents to 67 cents a share. The company's price target was also cut to $10 from $18. World Heart plummets after earnings warning (10:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- World Heart Corp WHRT shares plummeted Tuesday after the maker of medical devices warned that third- and fourth-quarter earnings will miss estimates due to weaker-than-expected sales. The Ottawa-based company also said it will restate its first-quarter results, noting that it has not received payment on a sale of 20 of its Novacor heart implants. The adjusted totals will shave $1 million off revenue and add $500,000 to its net loss. Analyst Jason Kroll at Roth Capital cut his estimates on the news but stuck with a "buy" rating on the stock. "Over the next few quarters, World Heart's management team must demonstrate the ability to execute and commercialize what we characterize as a strong produt offering and viable target market," he said. Shares were last trading down 44.5 percent at $2.15. Volme was 560,000 shares traded against an average daily volume of 47,000. Option Care shares soar on higher Q2, 2004 outlook (10:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Option Care OPTN, -0.99% soared Tuesday in morning trading after the company said it expects to exceed consensus estimates for both earnings and revenues for the second quarter of 2004. The health care company said its expects earnings for the quarter to come in at 21 cents a share on revenues of around $98 million. The current Thomson First Call average is for earnings of 19 cents on revenues of $91.9 million. Option Care also raised its 2004 outlook, saying it now expects to earn in the range of 84 cents to 87 cents per share compared to its prior estimate of 75 cents to 80 cents a share. The First Call average estimate is for full-year earnings of 78 cents a share. CEO Raj Rai did not rule a further upward revision in its 2004 outlook if "certain positive developments materialize." Option Care shares hit a 52-week high of $18.62 and were last trading up $3.38, or 23.8 percent, at $17.59. SpectraLink tumbles as Q2 warning sparks downgrades (10:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of SpectralLink SLNK slumped Tuesday as analysts rushed to downgrade the company after it warned on its second quarter results overnight. Raymond James analyst Chris Quilty lowered his view on the maker of short-range wireless telephone systems to "market perform" from "outperform." He also trimmed his 2004 earnings estimate by 8 cents to 49 cents a share and his 2005 estimate by 9 cents to 63 cents a share. Nevertheless, Quilty said SpectraLink is still poised to become one of the more dynamic "growth stories" in the sector despite this near-term weakness, with revenues possibly picking up as early as the next quarter. Over at JP Morgan, analyst Paul Coster downgraded the San Francisco-based company to "underweight" from "neutral," and lowered his earnings forecast for 2004 and 2005. He sadi that slow orders at the end of the second quarter show that market adoption of its short-range wireless telephone systems is not accelerating as open-standard IP-based PBXs or in-company telephone exchanges win market share. Coster however says the company's near-term issues are not insurmountable. He believes its shift toward a mixed retail and wholesale product offering should lead to "higher unit shipments and higher gross profitability over time." Shares of SpectraLink hit a 52-week low of $9.68 and were last trading down 20.3 percent at $9.75. Select Comfort hits 1-yr. low on warning, downgrade (9:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Shares of Select Comfort SCSS tumbled $6.48, or 27 percent, to $17.96 after the bed retailer warned that 2004 results would fall short of expectations, amid sluggish sales of middle to lower priced products and softening overall consumer spending. The stock hit a low of $17.55 in intraday trading, the lowest price seen early July 2003. Piper Jaffray followed by downgrading the stock to "market perform" from "outperform," and its stock price target to $21 from $34. "While we believe the long-term growth outlook remains intact, we believe that uncertainties surrounding near-term sales trends will limit the upside in Select Comfort shares," analyst Michael Cox said in a note to clients. Financial stocks flat at open (9:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Financial stocks traded little-changed as investors digested a slew of earnings from key banks on Tuesday. The Philadelphia Bank Index $BKX rose marginally, and the Amex Securities Broker Dealer Index $XBD added 0.2 percent. Merrill Lynch MER, -2.35% fell 0.2 percent after posting weaker-than-expected results. Duke to pay $207.5M to settle litigation (9:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Duke Energy DUK, +0.06% said it would provide $207.5 million in cash and credits to settle litigation with several states and federal regulators. As a result, the company will record a $104.9 million charge to second-quarter results, which includes $102.6 million in reserve and associated offsets. California, Washington and Oregon, several utilities and federal regulators claimed that Duke received unjust or unreasonable rates for the sale of electricity during January 2000 to June 2001. The stock closed Monday down 8 cents at $20.47. Marshall & Ilsley Q2 net beat Street estimates by 1c (8:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Marshall & Ilsley Corp MI posted second quarter net income of $151.7 million, or 67 cents a share compared with $134.7 million, or 59 cents a share in the year ago quarter. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 66 cents a share. Net interest income for the quarter climbed to $292 million from $271.8 million. Total non-interest revenues rose to $330 million from $294.7 million. The First Call average estimate was for total revenues of $610.3 million. Shares of Marshall & Ilsley were up 34 cents, or 0.9 percent at $39.10 at the close of trading Monday. Gannett June rev. rose 7.9% (8:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Gannett GCI, +0.50% said June operating revenue rose 7.9 percent over the same period a year ago to $612.7 million, helped by a 9.8 percent rise in advertising revenue. Within advertising, classified revenue increased 11 percent, national advertising grew 8.9 percent and local advertising rose 8.6 percent. The stock closed Monday up 46 cents at $81.39. Jefferies Q2 earnings up 56%, tops forecasts (8:29 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Investment bank Jefferies JEF said second quarter earnings per share rose 56 percent to 50 cents per share vs. 32 cents in the year-ago quarter. The EPS rise compared to Thomson First Call consensus estimates of 45 cents a share. Net earnings rose 70 percent to $31.8 million, and revenue rose 20 percent to $277.2 million, helped by rising investment bank and asset management. Trading revenue rose just 1 percent to $148 million. Johnson & Johnson beats Q2 earnings forecast (8:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% reported second-quarter earnings of 82 cents per share, up from 40 cents per share in the year-ago period. The pharmaceutical and householde products giant beat the forecast of 79 cents in a survey of analysts by Thomson Financial. Sales at the component of the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% rose 11 percent to $11.5 billion. Shares fell 10 cents to $54.89 on Monday. Gannett matches Q2 earns forecasts, ups stock buyback (8:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Gannett GCI, +0.50% reported second-quarter net income of $354.4 million, or $1.30 a share, up from $1.20 a share in the same period a year ago, and in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Total revenue rose 9.9 percent to $1.87 billion, amid a 9.8 percent increase in newspaper revenue and 10 percent growth in broadcasting revenue. Separately, the newspaper publisher said it increased its stock repurchase program by $1 billion. The company said a "substantial portion" of its previous $500 million buyback program had been used. The stock closed Monday up 46 cents at $81.39. Red Hat to restate financial results (8:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Red Hat RHAT said it would restate financial results for fiscal years 2004, 2003 and 2002 to reflect a change in the recognition of revenue from subscription agreements. The company said it determined, after a discussion with its independent auditors, that it was not appropriate to report subscription agreement revenue on a monthly basis, and should beginning recognizing the revenue on a daily basis. The company expects the restatement to result in "significant percentage differences" to quarterly operating profits and net income, but does not expect a "material" effect on its annual revenue or to its cash flow. The Linux operating system company's stock was trading down 85 cents at $19.50 in pre-open trading. AmSouth Q2 net beats Street estimates by a penny (8:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- AmSouth Bancorp ASO, -3.41% posted second quarter net income of $167 million, or 47 cents a share compared with $154.8 million, or 44 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 46 cents a share. Net interest income for the quarter climbed to $361.4 million, while noninterest revenue rose 3.6 percent to $218.3 million compared with the year-ago period. Noninterest revenue includes earnings for service charges, trust, investment management services, securities gains and other sources of fee income. The First Call average estimate was for total revenues of 601.4 million. Shares of AmSouth were up 22 cents, or 0.9 percent, at $24.79 at the close of trading Monday. Fastenal Q2 earns rise, top expectations (7:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Fastenal FAST, +2.65% reported second-quarter net earnings of $34.8 million, or 46 cents a share, up from 29 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 42 cents a share. Net sales rose 25 percent to $310.1 million, vs. analyst forecasts of $309.3 million. Gross profit margins for the first half of the year have increased 1 percentage point to 50.5 percent, as rising steel prices has resulted in increased selling prices. The industrial supply company's stock closed Monday down 33 cents at $54.41. Merrill Lynch Q2 rises, but misses Wall Street target (7:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Merrill Lynch MER, -2.35% said Tuesday its second quarter net income net income rose as earnings growth at its private client and investment management business helped offset weakness at its investment banking and global markets businesses. The company earned $1.06 per share, or $1.08 billion on revenues of $5.3 billion, compared to earnings of $1 per share, or $977 million a year ago, on revenues of $5.27 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected the company to earn $1.09 per share. BB&T Q2 net handily beats Street estimates (7:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- BB&T BBT, +0.99% posted second quarter net income of $400.1 million, or 72 cents a share compared to $316.2 million, or 67 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 68 cents a share. Net interest income jumped 19.4 percent to 839.7 million from 703.4 million while non-interest income soared 24 percent to $573.7 million compared with the same period a year ago, buoyed by contributions from acquisitions. The First Call average estimate was for total revenues of $1.35 billion. Shares of BB&T were up 1.9 percent at $37.38 at the close of trading Monday. State Street Q2 net turns to profit (7:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Boston-based bank State Street Corp STT, +1.91% said rising fees helped lift it second quarter results to a profit form a loss a year ago. The company earned 65 cents per share, or $220 million, from a loss of 7 cents per share, or $23 million a year ago. On an operating basis in 2004's second quarter, the company earned 68 cents per share, or $231 million, meeting Wall Street analyst estimates as compiled by Thomson First Call. Aaon sees Q2 net substantially lower vs. Q1 (7:34 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Aaon AAON, +1.04% warned Tuesday that it expects second quarter net earnings to be "substantially less than the first quarter of 2004," due to the continued impact of higher steel and copper prices. The Tulsa, Oklahoma-based company also attributed its lower forecast to start-up costs associated with a new coil project, a loss incurred by Aaon Canada and equipment failures at its Longview, Texas plants. Aaon did not provide any specific earnings forecast. The Thomson First Call average estimate is currently for earnings of 23 cents a share. Aaon however said it does expect to record record sales for the quarter due to a record backlog and some contribution revenues from Aaon Canada. Shares of Aaon were up 1.4 percent at $19.40 at the close of trading Monday. First Charter Q2 net beats Street estimates by 1c (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- First Charter FCTR, +1.20% posted second quarter net income of $10.3 million, or 34 cents a share, compared to a net loss of $4.2 million, or 14 cents a share in the same period in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 33 cents a share. Total revenues for the quarter edged lower to $44.9 million from $46.3 million against a First Call average of $45.3 million. Net interest income however rose $4 million, or 15 percent to $30 million compared to the year-ago period. Provision for loan losses dropped to $2 million in the quarter compared with $19.5 million in the same quarter a year ago. Shares of First Charter were up 7 cents at $21.03 at the close of trading Monday. Media General Q2 earns rise, but miss expectations (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Media General MEG, +4.36% reported second-quarter net income of $18.5 million, or 78 cents a share, up from 75 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 84 cents a share. The company said earnings from its partial ownership of SP Newsprint were "well below" expectations, amid rising raw materials and energy costs, and offset strength in its broadcast and publishing divisions. Total revenue rose 6.7 percent to $224.9 million, vs. analyst forecasts of $225.4 million. Looking ahead, the newspaper and TV station operator expects third-quarter earnings to be in the middle of the range of analyst estimates of 55 to 74 cents a share. The stock closed Monday down 39 cents at $62.60. Delta to record $1.65 billion in charges in Q2 (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63% said it would take a total of $1.65 billion in charges during the second quarter. Of the total, $1.53 billion in charges is related to deferred income taxes. Given that higher than expected fuel costs and lower than anticipated yields has hurt its actual and projected financial results in 2004, the company can no longer be sure if it can generate enough taxable income to use its deferred income tax assets. As a result, the air carrier must record a reserve against its net deferred income tax assets. The balance of the charges is related to its defined benefit pension plan for pilots. The stock closed Monday up 24 cents at $6.75. Russell expects Q2 earns to exceed expectations (7:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Russell RML, -11.76% said it expects second-quarter earnings to exceed expectations, helped by accelerated cost savings and improved manufacturing efficiencies. The athletic apparel seller now expects earnings, excluding non-recurring items of 20 to 22 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 15 cents a share. Including a one-time gain from the sale of its interest in Marmot Mountain, earnings are expected to be 28 to 30 cents a share. Russell's stock closed Monday down 4 cents at $17.05. Pubs group Wetherspoon lower after warning (3:59 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. pubs group JD Wetherspoon(UK:JDW)fell 4.3 percent after saying pre-tax profits for the fiscal year will be below the range of analyst forecasts due to the present sales growth. Like-for-like sales were flat for the 11 weeks to July 11, due to stronger competition from supermarkets and pubs, combined with the effect of the Euro 2004 soccer tournament, it said. Wetherspoon had warned in late April that profits could be around the low end of analyst estimates. Philips tops Q2 estimates on chips, affiliated units (2:13 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Philips Electronics PHG, +0.79% (NL:00953)on Tuesday said second quarter net income jumped to 616 million euros, from 42 million in the year-ago quarter as its chip division returned to profitability and unconsolidated companies boosted profits. That trumped net profit estimates between 485 million and 580 million euros, according to an AFX News poll. The Dutch consumer electronics group said sales improved 11 percent to 7.28 billion euros, with its chip division showed 28 percent comparable growth from mobile communications, and its Consumer Electronics division reporting 19 percent comparable growth on Connected Displays and Mobile Infotainment. Unconsolidated companies, such as its LG Philips LCD display division and InterTrust Technologies, contributed 430 million euros of profits vs. 108 million a year ago. It added it is confident in revenue and earnings growth in the second half, due to innovation pipeline, a well-filled order book and a reduced cost structure. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: U.S. stock futures were stepping higher, setting the stage for a solid start as a $1.4 billion financial services acquisition surfaced. Bank of America BAC, +2.04% it is paying $26.60 a share to acquire National Processing, creating the nation's second largest bancard merchant. A strong profits report at Philips PHG, +0.79% the largest electronics maker in Europe, also emerged, but tech stock trading was mixed. Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% a Dow industrials stock, beat the forecast as sales rose 11 percent to $11.5 billion. Wall Street's Merrill Lynch MER, -2.35% missed the per share average estimate from analysts for the June quarter. The U.S. trade deficit narrowed by 4.5 percent in May to $46.0 billion; it marked the first narrowing of the trade deficit in six months. See Indications for full pre-open coverage Global Markets Auto stocks were higher in Europe amid solid June sales. Asian stocks were mixed overnight. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker Action FuelCell Energy FCEL, +0.58% rallied 62 cents, or 6.5 percent, to $10.15 after First Albany upgraded the fuel cell maker to "buy" from "neutral" with a $15 price target on the stock. The broker cited the company's product cost strategy. See Internet's most complete source for analyst comments. Breaking news - See market pulse for breaking news Nortel Networks NT said it expects 2004 revenue to grow faster than the market, which it now believes will grow in the low to mid single digit percentage range. The company added that there has been no "material" development since it last provided a status update on June 2. Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% gained 90 cents to $70.35 after the company declared a 2 for 1 stock split and raised its quarterly dividend to 14 cents a share from 10 cents. Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63% said it would take a total of $1.65 billion in charges during the second quarter. Of the total, $1.53 billion in charges is related to deferred income taxes. Given that higher than expected fuel costs and lower than anticipated yields has hurt its actual and projected financial results in 2004, the company can no longer be sure if it can generate enough taxable income to use its deferred income tax assets. Merrill Lynch's second quarter net income net income rose as earnings growth at its private client and investment management business helped offset weakness at its investment banking and global markets businesses. The company earned $1.06 per share, or $1.08 billion on revenues of $5.3 billion, compared to earnings of $1 per share, or $977 million a year ago, on revenues of $5.27 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected the company to earn $1.09 per share. Red Hat RHAT said it would restate financial results for fiscal years 2004, 2003 and 2002 to reflect a change in the recognition of revenue from subscription agreements. The company expects the restatement to result in "significant percentage differences" to quarterly operating profits and net income, but does not expect a "material" effect on its annual revenue or to its cash flow. The Linux operating system company's stock was trading down 85 cents at $19.50 in pre-open trading. Boston-based bank State Street Corp STT, +1.91% said rising fees helped lift it second quarter results to a profit form a loss a year ago. The company earned 65 cents per share, or $220 million, from a loss of 7 cents per share, or $23 million a year ago. On an operating basis in 2004's second quarter, the company earned 68 cents per share, or $231 million, meeting Wall Street analyst estimates as compiled by Thomson First Call. Aaon AAON, +1.04% warned it expects second quarter net earnings to be "substantially less than the first quarter of 2004," due to the continued impact of higher steel and copper prices. Select Comfort SCSS slumped $5.14, or 21 percent, to $19.30 after the home furniture retailer warned late Monday that 2004 results would fall short of expectations. Fastenal FAST, +2.65% reported second-quarter net earnings of $34.8 million, or 46 cents a share, up from 29 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 42 cents a share. Net sales rose 25 percent to $310.1 million, vs. analyst forecasts of $309.3 million. Publicis PUB, -1.52% the French ad group, is no longer interested in bidding for Grey Global GREY CEO Maurice Levy told France's Le Figaro newspaper, AFX News reported. Publicis interest in Grey waned after its acquisition of Bcom3, Levy said. Publicis shares rose 2.8 percent in Paris. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets N.Y. title: BAC, JNJ, MER, FCEL, QCOM, RHAT

content: Tuesday's stocks to watch Merrill Lynch MER, -2.35% said Tuesday its second quarter net income rose, but missed expectations, as earnings growth at its private client and investment management business helped offset weakness at its investment banking and global markets businesses. The company earned $1.06 per share, or $1.08 billion on revenues of $5.3 billion, compared to earnings of $1 per share, or $977 million a year ago, on revenues of $5.27 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected the company to earn $1.09 per share. Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% declared a two-for-one stock split and a quarterly dividend increase. The split will be paid as a stock dividend on Aug. 13 to shareholders of record as of July 23. Qualcomm's board has approved a 40 percent increase to its quarterly dividend to 14 cents per share, pre-split, from its prior payout of 10 cents. The new dividend will be effective Sept. 24 for stockholders of record as of Aug. 27. Qualcomm closed Monday down $1.11 at $69.45. Oracle ORCL, +1.71% late Monday extended its unsolicited tender offer, currently $21 a share, for PeopleSoft. The bid was to expire July 16. Oracle said that its offer would now expire Aug. 27 and that it has tendered 4.7 million shares so far in favor of the takeover. PeopleSoft has roughly 365 million shares outstanding. See full story. Nortel Networks NT said it expects 2004 revenue to grow faster than the market, which it now believes will grow in the low to mid single digit percentage range. The company added that there has been no "material" development since it last provided a status update on June 2. Nortel said it needs to improve its cost structure, and will take "necessary steps" to remain competitive. Regarding the restatement of its financial results, the telecommunications equipment company will provide bi-weekly updates and continues to believe it will announce limited results for the first and second quarters by mid-August. The stock closed Monday down 14 cents at $4.23. Delta Air Lines d DAL, +1.63% said it would take a total of $1.65 billion in charges during the second quarter. Of the total, $1.53 billion in charges is related to deferred income taxes, and the balance of the charges is related to its defined benefit pension plan for pilots. The stock closed Monday up 24 cents at $6.75. BB&T BBT, +0.99% posted second quarter net income of $400.1 million, or 72 cents a share compared to $316.2 million, or 67 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 68 cents a share. Net interest income jumped 19.4 percent to 839.7 million from 703.4 million while non-interest income soared 24 percent to $573.7 million compared with the same period a year ago, buoyed by contributions from acquisitions. The First Call average estimate was for total revenues of $1.35 billion. Shares of BB&T were up 1.9 percent at $37.38 at the close of trading Monday. Media General MEG, +4.36% reported second-quarter net income of $18.5 million, or 78 cents a share, up from 75 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 84 cents a share. The company said earnings from its partial ownership of SP Newsprint were "well below" expectations, amid rising raw materials and energy costs, and offset strength in its broadcast and publishing divisions. Total revenue rose 6.7 percent to $224.9 million, vs. analyst forecasts of $225.4 million. Looking ahead, the newspaper and TV station operator expects third-quarter earnings to be in the middle of the range of analyst estimates of 55 to 74 cents a share. The stock closed Monday down 39 cents at $62.60. Russell RML, -11.76% said it expects second-quarter earnings to exceed expectations, helped by accelerated cost savings and improved manufacturing efficiencies. The athletic apparel seller now expects earnings, excluding non-recurring items of 20 to 22 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 15 cents a share. Including a one-time gain from the sale of its interest in Marmot Mountain, earnings are expected to be 28 to 30 cents a share. Russell's stock closed Monday down 4 cents at $17.05. Aaon AAON, +1.04% warned Tuesday that it expects second quarter net earnings to be "substantially less than the first quarter of 2004," due to the continued impact of higher steel and copper prices. The Tulsa, Oklahoma-based company also attributed its lower forecast to start-up costs associated with a new coil project, a loss incurred by Aaon Canada and equipment failures at its Longview, Texas plants. Aaon did not provide any specific earnings forecast. The Thomson First Call average estimate is currently for earnings of 23 cents a share. Aaon however said it does expect to record sales for the quarter due to a record backlog and some contribution revenues from Aaon Canada. Shares of Aaon were up 1.4 percent at $19.40 at the close of trading Monday. Oakley OO said an unexpected slowdown in second-quarter sales could bring full-year profits in at the bottom end of expectations. See full story. Higher production costs will also hurt the eyewear and footwear company, which said it now expects to earn between 60 cents and 65 cents per share in 2004 on sales of $575 million to $585 million. That is adjusted from a previous target of 65 cents a share on sales of $585 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for Oakley to earn 67 cents per share on the year. Compuware CPWR, -11.67% shares tumbled more than 4 percent in the extended-hours session Monday, after the company warned that its fiscal first-quarter results will fall short of expectations due to weaker software license sales. Shares of the Detroit-based business software company had lost just under a percent in the regular session to close at $6.01. See full story. Compuware now expects to post break-even results for its first quarter to June 30, on sales of around $286 million. In the same quarter a year earlier, the company earned 1 cent a share on sales of $306 million. Analysts had, on average, expected the company to post earnings of 3 cents a share on sales of $313.8 million, according to a Thomson First Call survey of five analysts. MI Developments MIM, +4.37% announced plans to take horse racetrack operator Magna Entertainment MECA private in a deal valued at $285.8 million in cash and stock. Under terms of the deal, each outstanding Class A stock not already owned by MID will be exchanged for $1.05 in cash and 0.2258 MID shares. Based on Monday's closing prices, Magna shares are being valued at $7 each, or a 22 percent premium. MID currently owns all of Magna's Class B shares and about 17 percent of the outstanding Class A shares. MID shares closed Monday down 34 cents at $26.35 and Magna shares rose 14 cents to $5.76. The U.S. Justice Department said that United Airlines UALAQ will pay $850,000 to settle allegations of hazardous waste violations at San Francisco International Airport. An advisory committee of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has recommended that the agency not approve Tazoral, Allergan's AGN, +1.59% oral medication for psoriasis. See full story. Semiconductor maker LSI Logic LSI, -0.35% warned that its second-quarter revenue figure would fall below its previous estimate due to "softer-than-anticipated demand for semiconductors in storage components and video game console markets." LSI now sees revenue of $448 million, compared to its earlier forecast of $455 million to $470 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting to see a figure of $462.8 million, on average. The company also said it expects a second-quarter profit from operations of 6 cents a share to 8 cents a share, consistent with its previous forecast, along with EPS of 1 cent a share to 3 cents a share on a GAAP basis, also in line with the earlier estimate. Corporate uniform distributor Cintas CTAS, +0.91% beat Wall Street expectations of its fourth-quarter profit by a penny a share. The company reported income of $72.7 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with $65.2 million, or 38 cents a share, a year ago. Cintas reported sales of $567.1 million, up from $528, 623. McDonald's MCD, -1.28% said that its popular Rock 'N' Roll restaurant in downtown Chicago will be leveled for the restaurant of the future -- a two-story, glass-clad eatery that will feature wireless Internet and a rooftop garden. McDonald's said the new restaurant would open in 2005. See full story. Shares of Select Comfort SCSS fell 26 percent in after-hours trade Monday on news that the company expects to report financial results lower than previously anticipated. Select Comfort reiterated its estimate for the second quarter, but warned that sluggish sales may negatively impact its full-year 2004 results. See full story. The Minneapolis-based bed retailer is anticipating second-quarter earnings of 13 cents to 15 cents per share, with revenue of $124.7 million. It also expects to report a 14 percent increase in same-store sales. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call peg the second-quarter earnings outlook at 15 cents per share with revenue of $130 million, and are looking for full-year 2004 earnings of 95 cents per share with revenue of $586 million. Scholastic Corp. SCHL, +0.21% publisher of the "Harry Potter" novels, said that it expects to post charges of about $25 million in its fiscal fourth quarter related to discontinued programs, prepaid promotion costs, bad debt expense and other items at its direct-to-home continuity business. See full story. Red Robin Gourmet Burgers RRGB, -0.51% raised its second-quarter outlook, citing improved sales at its restaurants. See full story. Fair Isaac FIC, +0.00% lowered its outlook for the third and fourth quarters, citing lower one-time software license fees. For the fiscal third quarter, the company expects an earnings range of 38 cents to 40 cents a share, lower than its previous estimate of 40 cents to 43 cents a share and expects revenue of $173 million to $175 million, down from its earlier forecast of $185 million to $189 million. Fair Isaac revised its fourth-quarter estimate as well, with an earnings outlook of 25 cents to 27 cents a share, lower than its previous estimate of 40 cents to 43 cents a share. The Minneapolis-based company expects fourth-quarter revenue of $185 million to $189 million, down from its earlier forecast of $205 million to $211 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast third-quarter earnings of 42 cents a share, on revenue of $186 million, with fourth-quarter earnings of 42 cents a share on revenue of $208 million. World Heart Corp. said that it will restate its first-quarter results, and that third- and fourth-quarter earnings will fall short of estimates due to lower than expected sales of its medical devices. See full story. Intermagnetics IMGC reaffirmed its forecast for its 2005 revenue and operating earnings after receiving regulatory approval for its acquisition of MRI Devices. See full story. Braun Consulting BRNC said late Monday that second-quarter revenue would fall short of earlier expectations and also that it has hired an investment bank to explore a possible sale or merger. See full story. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Qualcomm, Merrill Lynch, Nortel Networks and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Aaon AAON, +1.04% warned Tuesday that it expects second quarter net earnings to be "substantially less than the first quarter of 2004," due to the continued impact of higher steel and copper prices. The Tulsa, Oklahoma-based company also attributed its lower forecast to start-up costs associated with a new coil project, a loss incurred by Aaon Canada and equipment failures at its Longview, Texas plants. Aaon did not provide any specific earnings forecast. The Thomson First Call average estimate is currently for earnings of 23 cents a share. Aaon however said it does expect to record record sales for the quarter due to a record backlog and some contribution revenues from Aaon Canada. Shares of Aaon were up 1.4 percent at $19.40 at the close of trading Monday.
title: Aaon sees Q2 net substantially lower  vs. Q1

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Air conditioner and heating equipment maker Aaon AAON, +1.04% said an error in calculating its weighted average shares outstanding in the fourth quarter has resulted in a 1 cent reduction of basic and diluted earnings per share. Earnings for the quarter now stand at 30 cents basic and 29 cents diluted. All other quarterly and 2003 results are unchanged. Shares ended Tuesday unchanged at $19.83.
title: Aaon corrects Q4 earns to 29c vs 30c

content: Telstra's first-half net income almost doubles (8:57 PM ET) TOKYO (CBS.MW) -- Telstra TLS, +0.58% Australia's biggest phone company, on Thursday said its net income almost doubled in the six months ended Dec. 31 from the year-ago period even though it wrote off investments in Hong Kong cable joint venture Reach. Net income jumped 93.7 percent to A$2.29 billion ($1.8 billion), or 17.9 cents a share, from A$1.18 billion, or 9.2 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales fell 4.7 percent to A$10.8 billion from year-ago levels. Analysts expected first-half net income of A$2.173 billion, according to a Reuters poll. The company kept the full-year outlook unchanged. Shares of Telstra fell 1.5 percent to A$4.75 Thursday in Sydney. Quovadx sees profitable 2004; shares rise more than 12% (5:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Quovadx QVDX shares added more than 12 percent in late trade after the company, which provides software to the health care industry, said it expected to swing to a profit in 2004. The Englewood, Colo.-based company said it expects to make 1-3 cents a share on sales of between $30 million and $32 million for the first quarter. For the year, Quovadx expects earnings of 17-20 cents a share on sales of between $130 million and $135 million. For the fourth quarter, the firm posted a loss of $508,000, or a penny a share, vs. a loss of $3.5 million, or 11 cents a share, the year before. Sales rose to $26.3 million from $15.6 million. Shares of Quovadx added 75 cents to $6.75 in after-hours dealings. Medco Health Solutions profit rises 10% (5:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Medco Health Solutions, the nation's largest pharmacy benefits manager, said Wednesday that fourth-quarter net income was $118.3 million, or 43 cents a share, compared with $107.2 million, or 40 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding a charge of 5 cents a share to reflect the reduced value of certain assets, the Franklin Lakes, N.J.-based firm earned 48 cents a share, beating the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call of 46 cents. Revenue came in at $9 billion, up from $8.54 billion last year. Shares of Medco MHS rose 79 cents to close at $37.99 Wednesday. Quidel ups 2004 forecast, shares rise more than 5% (5:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Quidel QDEL, +0.54% share gained more than 5 percent late Wednesday after the company upped its 2004 forecast. The diagnostic test maker said it expects to report earnings of 39-44 cents a share on sales of $104 million to $109 million, vs. a previous forecast of 38-41 cents a share on sales of $100 million. Quidel reported a profit of $18.8 million, or 59 cents a share, on sales of $33.2 million for the fourth quarter. Last year, the firm made $1 million, or 3 cents a share, on sales of $22.8 million. Quidel also said that chairman Andre de Bruin would not seek re-election. The stock added 70 cents in late dealings, to $13.75. Yum glides by expectations, raises forecast (4:54 PM ET) CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- Strong sales at Taco Bell and international stores fueled a 24 percent jump in earnings for Yum Brands to $214 million, or 70 cents a share, from $172 million, or 56 cents a share last year. The nation's second-largest restaurant chain said total sales climbed 8 percent to $2.65 billion. Excluding a one-time gain, Yum would have reported income of 65 cents a share. Those results were 3 cents ahead of the average view of analysts' reporting to Reuters Research. Yum, which also is the parent of KFC and Pizza Hut, raised full-year earnings projections to at least $2.27 a share, up from the Wall Street forecast of $2.24 a share. Yum YUM, +1.04% shares ended the session at $33.71, up 53 cents. Medtronic's Q3 profit up 9%, meets estimate (4:41 PM ET) BOSTON (CBS.MW) -- No. 1 medical device maker Medtronic MDT, +2.24% said late Wednesday that its fiscal third-quarter profit rose 9 percent to $464.4 million, or 38 cents per share, compared with $427.7 million, or 35 cents per share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding one-time charges, Medtronic said its profit in the latest period was $486.4 million, or 40 cents per share, which was in line with expectations, according to the average estimate of analysts polled by Reuters Research. Medtronic shares were unchanged at $47.38 in after-hours dealings. Whole Foods profit soars 51% (4:38 PM ET) CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- Whole Foods reported a first-quarter profit of $38.7 million, or 60 cents a share, that was 51 percent above last year's income of $25.6 million, or 42 cents a share. Total sales reached a record $1.11 billion, up 21 percent, thanks to new stores and lower costs to open them. Same-store sales climbed 12.8 percent. The results were 3 cents ahead of the average analysts' forecast, according to Reuters Research. Whole Foods WFMI shares ended the session at $73.30, up $1.18, ahead of the news. In intraday trading, shares reached a fresh 52-week high of $73.73. Opsware raises revenue estimates (4:27 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Computer software maker Opsware reported Wednesday it expects fourth-quarter sales of about $6.2 million, exceeding its previous estimate. Opsware OPSW also said annual revenue is on track to total an estimated $18 million. Brocade Communications: Q1 net loss of $36.8 mln (4:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Brocade Communications BRCD said Wednesday it had a first-quarter net loss of $36.8 million, or 14 cents a share, on revenue of $145 million. Excluding one-time items, the storage-networking company earned $8 million, or 3 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research estimated Brocade would earn 2 cents a share on $143.2 million. During the same period a year ago, Brocade posted breakeven earnings before charges on revenue of $123.1 million. Computer Sciences beats FQ3 target (4:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Computer Sciences CSC, +3.70% on Wednesday said it earned $128.4 million, or 68 cents a share, up from $105.7 million, or 61 cents a share a year earlier. Excluding about 3 cents a share for an after-tax special charge related to the company's acquisition of DynCorp, Computer Sciences earned 71 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected the company to earn 70 cents a share, on average. Revenue was $3.62 billion, up 29.6 percent over the third quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected sales of $3.63 million, on average. Computer Sciences shares rose 45 cents, or 1 percent, to $46.62 in regular-session Nasdaq trading, ahead of the announcement. VF Corp. posts Q4 earnings rise on Nautica acquisition (3:29 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Clothing retailer VF Corp. VF said Wednesday that earnings from operations amounted to 96 cents a share in the fourth quarter versus 63 cents a share in 2002. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had pegged earnings per share at 90 cents. The company said income from continuing operations was $105.6 million versus $70.3 million in the year ago period. The Greensboro, N.C.-based company said its acquisition of sportswear clothier Nautica added 11 cents a share to earnings for the quarter. Sales rose 6 percent to $1.4 billion against the $1.3 billion from a year ago. Shares fell 5 cents to $44.74 in late afternoon trading. H-P sees Q1 results in line w/ Wall St. view (2:59 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% said it expects earnings before items of 35 cents per share on revenue of $19.5 billion for the first quarter. This outlook is roughly in line with the mean estimate of analysts polled by Reuters Research for a clean profit of 35 cents per share on revenue of $19.4 billion. On a GAAP (generally accepted accounting principles) basis, the Palo Alto, Calif., computer hardware firm sees earnings of 30 to 31 cents per share for the quarter. The company expects to record 4 to 5 cents per share in charges related to adjustments for amortization of purchased intangibles. H-P plans to release its results after the closing bell on Feb. 19. The stock rose 2.6 percent to $24.76 in late trades. Firstwave drops following Q4 loss (2:43 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Firstwave Technologies FSTW fell more than 12 percent to $5.29 after the Atlanta-based provider of customer relationship management applications posted a loss of $640,000, or 24 cents per share, for the fourth quarter, down from its profit of $486,000, or 22 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier.
