The company said the latest results reflect lower services revenue following the completion of a multi-year project, and efforts to diversify its customer base. Hauppage Digital gets boost from strong Q1 earnings (2:23 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Hauppage Digital HAUP, +0.40% shares rose more than 15 percent to $4.93 after the digital video television receiver maker reported first-quarter earnings of $992,860, or 11 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $656,472, or 7 cents per share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Sales leapt 17 percent in the latest three months to $18.2 million from $15.5 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the improved results to increases in both OEM sales of its WinTV personal video recorder products for use with Microsoft's MSFT, +2.10% Media Center Edition and retail sales of the WinTV product. It also cited higher European digital product sales, and new product introductions. Genus stumbles; Needham says outlook disappointing (1:43 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Genus GGNS shares lost more than 13 percent to $3.76 on heavy volume of 3.1 million, more than six times the issue's daily average. After Tuesday's closing bell, the Sunnyvale, Calif., maker of chip capital equipment posted fourth-quarter earnings of $268,000, or a penny per share, better than its year-ago loss of $2.7 million, or 9 cents per share, and ahead of the mean estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a loss of a penny per share. However, Needham & Co. said the company offered a "disappointingly modest" outlook for 2004. The firm, which maintained its "hold" rating on the stock, said Genus forecast revenue of $55 million to $65 million for 2004, representing a decline of 3 to 14 percent from its 2003 total, and "well below our expectations of 30 percent capital spending growth" for the year. Needham lowered its earnings estimates for 2004, and said it believes the company's contention that it's seeing an industry-wide slowdown in orders is a reflection of its heavy dependence on Samsung, which comprised about 70 percent of orders in the fourth quarter. Aaon slides in wake of cautious outlook (1:00 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Aaon Corp. AAON, +1.04% saw its stock fall more than 7 percent to $17.95 after the Tulsa, Okla., maker of air conditioning and heating equipment posted a year-over-year increase in quarterly results but cautioned investors that it can't accurately predict its near-term future performance due to uncertainties in the economy and the potential impact of its new products. For the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, the company posted earnings of $3.7 million, or 30 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $3.1 million, or 23 cents per share. The mean estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 27 cents per share. Escalon Medical jumps on strong Q2 results (12:31 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Escalon Medical ESMC, +3.45% shares gained more than 18 percent to $9.89 after the Wayne, Pa., medical products firm reported second-quarter earnings of $820,961, or 20 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of 347,672, or 10 cents per share. Revenue rose 15 percent in the latest three months to $3.8 million from $3.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said revenue from its Sonomed ophthalmic ultrasound equipment products jumped 21 percent in the latest quarter to $2 million, and that gross margins swelled to 60.3 percent from 53.5 percent a year earlier due to product mix and higher productivity due to increased volumes. Oakley hits 52-week high after strong Q4 report (12:18 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Oakley OO shares rose more than 7 percent to $15.17, pulling back slightly after hitting a 52-week high of $15.45 earlier in the session. The Foothill Ranch, Calif., sunglass seller reported fourth-quarter earnings of $3.2 million, or five cents per share, beating Wall Street's mean estimate by a penny. The results were well above its profit of $500,000, or a penny per share, in the same period a year earlier when the company recorded a restructuring charge of $1.8 million, or 2 cents per share. Sales jumped 18.1 percent in the latest three months to $121.6 million from $102.9 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Oakley forecast sales growth of about 10 percent, and earnings per share growth of 15 percent in 2004. Wilson Greatbatch slumps on weak Q4 (11:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Wilson Greatbatch Technologies GB, +18.75% shares slumped Wednesday after the manufacturer of components for medical devices and other applications missed fourth-quarter earnings estimates by five cents. Wilson reported earnings of 21 cents a share against 23 cents a year ago. Sales rose 4.3 percent to $49.4 million. Analyst Glenn Reicin at Morgan Stanley said the sales figure was light across most business lines as OEM (original equipment makers) customers reversed stocking trends from earlier in the year. Lower volumes weighed on gross margins and operating margins too, he said. Reicin cut his earnings estimate for 2004 to $1.40 from $1.47. "While we believe the stock is fairly valued, we caution investors not to overreact," he said. Shares were down 6.3 percent at $38.43. LeapFrog tumbles on Q4 report, outlook, CEO switch (11:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- LeapFrog Enterprises' LF shares fell more than 10 percent to $27.27 after Emeryville, Calif., maker of educational toys missed Wall Street's mean estimate for its fourth-quarter results by a penny, and said that it expects to record only 20 percent of its anticipated sales for fiscal 2004 in the first half of the year. The company also said it would no longer provide an outlook for its financials on a quarterly basis due to the seasonality of its business, and that Mike Wood, its founder, would move to the role of chief vision and creative officer, leaving the CEO and president positions. LeapFrog earned $44.2 million, or 72 cents per share, on sales of $331.3 million in the three months ended Dec. 31. In the same period a year earlier, the company posted a profit of $29.4 million, or 50 cents per share, on sales of $531.8 million. The company said its latest results were achieved despite its recording of a reserve related to the bankruptcy of KB Toys and airfreight expenses related to late, stronger-than-anticipated demand for certain products. Gross margins slipped to 50 percent in the latest quarter from 50.8 percent last year due to lower margins on its Leapster products. Looking ahead, LeapFrog sees earnings of $88 million to $95 million, or $1.39 to $1.51 per share, on sales ranging from $800 million to $850 million in 2004. Wall Street's current average analysts' estimate is for a profit of $1.47 per share in 2004. The company named Chairman Tom Kalinske to the CEO position, and Jerry Perez, most recently an executive vice president with Mattel, to the president post. HealthNet slumps on downbeat outlook (10:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- HealthNet HNT, +0.00% shares fell almost 12 percent in early trade to become the second-biggest percentage decliner on the New York Stock Exchange after providing a below-consensus outlook for 2004. The California health plan cut its outlook for the year to $2.92 to $3.07 from a prior $3.08 to $3.11, citing general market conditions and problems at its Northewast division. HealthNet also restated earnings for the first three quarters of 2003 and all of 2002 and 2001. The restatements, which adjust for workers' compensation, lease costs and other items, have added 3 cents per share to income for the first three quarters of 2003 but have no impact on fourth quarter earnings. Shares were last down 12.9 percent at $28.25. Milacron slides in wake of Q4 results (10:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Milacron MZ shares lost more than 11 percent to $3.26 after the Cincinnati provider of plastics-processing technologies and industrial fluids reported a loss of $24.4 million, or 72 cents per share, wider than its year-ago loss of $5.5 million, or 17 cents per share. The latest results include a non-cash goodwill impairment charge of $13.3 million, and pre-tax restructuring charges of $8.4 million. The company said its results from continuing operations were "consistent" with its outlook. Sales totaled $197.7 million in the latest three months. The mean estimate of five analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 6 cents per share in the December period on revenue of $191.2 million. Looking ahead, Milacron said it now expects to see a "substantial improvement" in its business results in the second half of 2004. CSFB says buy Coke 'on any pullback' after Q4 report (10:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Coca-Cola KO, +0.25% fell 86 cents, or 1.6 percent, to $51.31, and was the biggest percentage decliner among Dow industrials components, after the beverage behemoth reported fourth-quarter results. Analyst Andrew Conway at CS First Boston recommended buying the stock "on any pullback," saying the company's "mediocre" operating performance was "well advertised" by the company at the December investor meeting. While earnings and revenue topped Wall Street expectations, Conway noted that the company's North American and Asian operating profits declined, and that incentive compensation expenses increased. Conway reiterated his "outperform" rating on the stock. Disney tops Q4 estimates, revs up 19% CORRECT (10:03 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- The Walt Disney Co. DIS, +1.93% said it earned $688 million, or 33 cents a share, in the first quarter, up from $36 million, or 2 cents a share, a year ago, boosted by strong growth at its studio and media networks. The company released its earnings earlier than planned after it was the target of an unsolicited bid from Comcast CMCSA, +2.67% earlier today. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 23 cents a share. Revenue climbed 19 percent to $8.549 billion from $7.170 billion. CEO and chairman Michael Eisner said the figures "increase our confidence that we will deliver earnings growth from our continuing operations of more than 30 percent in 2004." Disney shares were last up 15.5 percent to $27.83. (Correcting to show year earlier earnings figure is 2 cents per share.) Garmin shares drop; co. sees Q1 below view (9:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Garmin GRMN, +1.24% shares lost more than 9 percent to $47.21 after the Cayman Islands-based maker of global positioning information devices posted fourth-quarter earnings of $54.6 million, or 50 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $45.5 million, or 41 cents per share. Excluding a $4.4 million gain from positive foreign currency translation, the company earned 47 cents per share in the quarter. The mean estimate of nine analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 45 cents per share in the December period. Revenue rose 27 percent in the latest three months to $170.1 million from $133.7 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Garmin forecast earnings before items of 35 to 37 cents per share on revenue of between $137 million and $140 million for the first quarter, and a profit of $1.80 to $1.94 per share on revenue ranging from $660 million to $690 million for the full year. Wall Street's current average analysts' estimates are for earnings of 43 cents per share and $1.92 per share, respectively. Harleysville takes $42 million charge to boost reserves (9:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW)-- Harleysville Group said Wednesday it will take a $42 million charge, or 92 cents a share, for the fourth quarter after the insurer increased its reserves at the end of 2003. Harleysville HGIC said it expects a diluted net loss per share in the range of $0.64 to $0.68 in the fourth quarter of 2003 and a diluted net loss per share in the range of $1.57 to $1.61 for the full year 2003. Analysts were expecting earnings of 35 cents a share for the quarter, according to Thomson First Call. The reserves were made to offset losses in past years in the company's workers compensation, commercial automobile liability, commercial multi-peril and personal automobile liability lines. Playboy Q4 loss widens; beats estimates by 2c (9:01 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Playboy Enterprises PLA, +0.00% said it had a net loss of $6.7 million, or 26 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, wider than the $4.0 million, or 16 cents a share loss posted a year ago as it booked charges to settle a lawsuit with Logix Development. Excluding those charges, the company earned 5 cents a share in the quarter, 2 cents higher than the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue climbed 24 percent to $91.1 million from $73.5 million last year. CEO Christie Hefner said the company is raising its 2004 operating profit outlook to $33 million from a prior $30 million and reiterating its forecast of a return to net profitability and positive earnings per share. Shares ended Tuesday up 4.4 percent at $15.78 Frontier Oil Q4 tops estimates on strong crude spreads (8:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Frontier Oil FTO, +1.91% said it earned $4.1 million, or 15 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, up from $3.0 million, or 11 cents a share, a year ago, boosted by strong crude oil spreads. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 14 cents a share. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization climbed to $22.5 million from $18.1 million a year ago. Frontier said the light/heavy crude oil spread was $7.66 per barrel in the quarter against $6.31 a year ago. Shares ended Tuesday up 3.7 percent at $17.75. Aon ok w/ current Wall St. view for 2004 (8:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Aon Corp. AOC, -3.71% reported fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $215 million, or 67 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent profit of $186 million, or 62 cents per share. Aon said it recorded unusual World Trade Center credits of 12 cents per share in the latest quarter. The mean estimate of 12 analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a clean profit of 55 cents per share in the December period. Revenue jumped 10 percent in the latest three months to $2.6 billion from $2.4 billion in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the increased sales to solid demand for its services and products, and the positive influence of foreign exchange rates. Looking ahead, Aon said it's comfortable that it will achieve or exceed the current average analysts' estimate for earnings of $2.17 per share in 2004. The stock closed Tuesday at $24.92, up 12 cents. News Corp.'s Q2 EPS ahead by 2 cents (8:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- News Corp. NWS, +1.90% reported second-quarter net income of $361 million, or 30 cents per share, up from $239 million, or 24 cents per share in the year-ago period. The Sydney-based media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch said revenue climbed to $5.6 billion, from $4.7 billion. The company beat the forecast of 28 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The company cited revenue growth in its cable channels; a slight rise in operating income in its TV segment, and flat operating income at its filmed entertainment unit. The company said its newspaper group saw higher earnings led by advertising and circulation revenue gains in the U.K. and Australia. Its BSkyB BSY, -11.76% satellite business saw revenue growth of 17 percent. The company also completed its acquisition of 34 percent of Hughes, owner of DirecTV, in the quarter. Shares of News Corp. rose 51 cents to $37.70 on Tuesday. Dana swings to Q4 profit (8:26 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Dana Corp. DWC, +1.57% swung to a fourth-quarter profit of $68 million, or 45 cents a share, reversing a year-ago loss of $9 million, or 6 cents a share. The results beat Wall Street's consensus estimate of 40 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Last year's results were impacted by charges related to the restructuring efforts. In the quarter, revenue rose to $2.1 billion, up from $1.8 billion in the prior year. Sales were bolstered by foreign currency, the Toledo, Ohio-based auto parts supplier said. Shares of Dana closed Tuesday up 47 cents at $22.90. Hercules posts in-line ongoing results for Q4 (8:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Hercules HPC, +5.08% reported fourth-quarter earnings before items of $13 million, or 12 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent profit of $11 million, or 10 cents per share. The Wilmington, Del., maker of specialty chemicals earned $20 million, or 18 cents per share, on an ongoing operations basis. This performance was in line with the mean estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Including a charge to increase its reserves for future asbestos-related costs and a charge from a change in an accounting principle, the company earned $8 million, or 8 cents per share, in the December quarter. Sales rose in the latest three months to $458 million from $423 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the company said it remains committed to its target for double-digit earnings per share growth, and that it anticipates further improvements in sales, earnings and cash flow in 2004. The stock closed Tuesday at $12.20, up 19 cents. Fox tops Q2 estimates on cable channel growth (8:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Fox Entertainment Group FOX, +2.45% said it earned $330 million, or 36 cents a share, in the second quarter, up from $283 million, or 32 cents a share, a year ago, boosted by growth at its cable channels. The Thomson First Call average estimate called for earnings of 34 cents a share. Revenue climbed 7 percent to $3.4 billion, driven by strong growth at its cable network programming and television broadcast network. Operating income before depreciation and amortization climbed 10 percent to $634 million. Shares ended Tuesday up 4 percent at $30.99. Landry's Restaurants tops in Q4 by 3c (8:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Landry's Restaurants LNY, -25.00% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 9 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $4.6 million, or 16 cents per share. The latest results include a gain from an income tax benefit of $6.3 million, and an asset impairment charge of $13.5 million. Excluding these items, the Houston-based casual dining seafood restaurant operator earned 19 cents per share, 3 cents ahead of the mean estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose to $254.1 million in the latest three months from $229.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-location sales gained 3.5 percent in the quarter. The stock closed Tuesday at $28.95, up 32 cents. SteelCloud warns of Q1 shortfall (8:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - SteelCloud SCLD warned that fiscal first-quarter results would fall short of expectations due to delays in the availability of software for its security appliances and lower-than-expected distribution sales. The network security company expects to lose 10 to 13 cents a share, the first loss in six quarters. Revenue is expected to be $4 to $4.5 million for the quarter ending January, down from revenue of $7.63 million in the year-earlier period. The company said it would consolidate and strengthen its sales and marketing operations, and focus them on target geographic and distribution channels. "We're not happy about it and are working diligently with our partners to make new products available before the current second quarter ends," said SteelCloud Chairman Thomas Dunne. The stock closed Tuesday up a nickel at $2.75. AIG posts higher profit on 27% revenue boost (7:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- American International Group AIG, -0.18% reported fourth-quarter net income of $2.71 billion, or $1.03 per share, compared with a loss of $103.8 million, or 3 cents per share in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income was $2.75 billion, or $1.05 per share, up from $537.5 million, or 20 cents per share in the year-ago period. Revenue climbed 26.5 percent to $22.18 billion, from $17.53 billion. The company beat the forecast of $1.04 per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The New York-based insurer cited "record" results in its general insurance, life insurance, financial services and retirement services and asset management units. The company sees "strong momentum for 2004 and beyond." Shares rose $1.67 to $73.50 on Tuesday. America's Car-Mart cuts Q3 outlook (7:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- America's Car-Mart CMRT cut its third-quarter earnings outlook to 34 to 37 cents a share from a prior 47 cents a share, citing a rise in charge-offs which has led it to increase loan loss provisions. The car retailer said sales are also slightly lower than expected. CEO T.J. Falgout said charge-offs increased to about $8.5 million, or 22 percent of sales, after the company decided to improve the quality of its portfolio by dealing more aggressively with slow-paying customers. The company is now expecting fourth-quarter earnings of 54 to 56 cents, compared with an earlier forecast of 56 cents. Shares closed Tuesday down 5.7 percent at $32.34. SkyWest Q4 tops estimates, revs up 14.1% (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- SkyWest SKYW, +0.83% said it earned $17.5 million, or 30 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with $17.8 million, or 31 cents a share a year ago. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 27 cents a share. Revene climbed 14.1 percent to $237.5 million. Skywest said a 33.7 percent rise in avilable seat miles was offset by a 17.8 percent reduction in yield per revenue passenger mile. Shares ended Tuesday up 2.8 percent at $20.30. Comcast swings to profit in Q4; sees FY04 revs up 10% (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Comcast CMCSA, +2.67% reported fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $383 million, or 17 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent loss of $105 million, or 7 cents per share. The mean estimate of 19 analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 3 cents per share in the December period. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $4.74 billion from $3 billion in the same period a year earlier. Operating cash flow swelled to $1.72 billion in the quarter from $905 million last year. The Philadelphia-based cable television services provider, which also announced plans for a proposed merger with Dow component Walt Disney DIS, +1.93% said its performance "achieved or exceeded all financial targets" set for 2003. Looking ahead, it forecast revenue growth of 10 percent for 2004, and reiterated an outlook for operating cash flow growth of 15 to 17 percent for the year. Also for 2004, Comcast expects basic subscriber growth of about 0.5 percent, high-speed Internet subscriber net additions of between 1.5 million and 1.6 million, and digital cable subscriber net additions of between 700,000 and 1 million. Class A voting shares of Comcast closed Tuesday at $33.93, up 2 percent. Protective Life tops Wall St. view for Q4 by nickel (7:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Protective Life PL, +0.00% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $67.6 million, or 95 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $30.3 million, or 43 cents per share. The latest results include net realized investment gains of 18 cents per share. The mean estimate of 13 analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a clean profit of 72 cents per share in the December period. As of Dec. 31, Protective Life had assets of $24.6 billion, up 12 percent from $21.9 billion at the end of 2002. The stock closed Tuesday at $36.45, up 1.4 percent. Coke tops Q4 earnings, revenue expectations (7:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Coca-Cola KO, +0.25% reported fourth-quarter net income of $927 million, or 38 cents a share, in line with earnings from the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, such as restructuring costs, earnings were 46 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of 44 cents. Total net operating revenue rose 7.9 percent to $5.18 billion, ahead of analyst forecasts of $5.03 billion. The beverage behemoth said results benefited from a lower-than-expected tax rate, and a gain from a litigation settlement helped offset higher costs of goods sold. Currency translation positively impacted operating income by 2 percent. The stock, a component of the Dow industrials, closed Tuesday down 23 cents at $52.17. XTO Energy exceeds Q4 earns, revenue forecasts (6:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - XTO Energy XTO, -0.46% reported fourth-quarter net income of $61.9 million, or 33 cents a share, in line with what it earned in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings were 49 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research, amid a 34 percent increase in natural gas production to a record 738 million cubic feet per day. Total revenue rose 39 percent to $331.85 million, ahead of analyst forecasts of $310.2 million. The natural gas producer's stock closed Tuesday up 99 cents at $27.60. Swift Energy Q4 earns, rev. rise above expectations (6:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Swift Energy SFY, -0.17% reported fourth-quarter net income of $9.5 million, or 34 cents a share, up from 12 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and well above the average analyst estimate of 27 cents a share, according to Reuters Research. Revenue rose 31 percent to $53.1 million, topping analyst forecasts of $51.5 million, due primarily to increased production and higher commodity prices. The oil and gas exploration company raised its first quarter domestic production projection to 10 to 10.5 billion cubic feet equivalent (Bcfe) from 9.7 to 10.2 Bcfe. The stock closed Tuesday up 31 cents at $17.25. Lamar Advertising Q4 loss a penny wider than estimates (6:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Lamar Advertising LAMR, -0.78% reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $5.96 million, or 6 cents a share, vs. a loss of 14 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and wider than the average analyst loss estimate of 5 cents a share, according to Reuters Research. Net revenue rose 5.8 percent to $206 million, and adjust EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) increased $88.1 million. Looking ahead, the operator of outdoor advertising displays expects revenue of $197 million in the first quarter and EBITDA to rise 7 percent. The stock closed Tuesday up 28 cents at $38.52. Office Depot Q4 earns, rev. match expectations (6:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Office Depot ODP, +0.94% reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $45.8 million, or 15 cents a share, down from 21 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding one-time items, such as lease termination costs and investment write-downs, earnings were 22 cents a share, in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research. Total sales rose 14 percent to $3.3 billion, matching analyst forecasts, while global same-store sales fell 2 percent. The office products retailer said strength in its North American delivery business and international operations helped offset weakness in retail. Looking ahead, the company expects total sales to rise 6 to 8 percent in 2004, with positive same-store sales in every quarter. The stock closed Tuesday down 25 cents at $16.70. Peugeot posts 11.4% '03 profit dip, no 1H upturn (2:40 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- French automaker PSA Peugeot Citroen(FR:012150)on Wednesday said 2003 net income dropped 11.4 percent to 1.497 billion euros, as operating margin contracted 24.6 percent to 2.195 billion euros, hit by the euro and the sharp drop in the French auto market. For 2003, sales eased 0.4 percent to 54.238 billion euros, or a 1.5 percent rise at constant exchange rates. It said the environment is unlikely to improve during the first half of 2004 either for automobile demand in France and the rest of Europe or for the euro. With new model launches scheduled for the second half, it sees moderate sales growth and operating margin about the same as in 2003. BSkyB broadcaster returns to dividends after 5 yr break (2:34 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- British satellite broadcaster BSkyB(UK:BSY)Wednesday said it was returning to paying a dividend to shareholders after a five-year break with an interim payment of 2.75 pence per share for the six months to Dec. 31. In a brief statement to the London Stock Exchange, the broadcaster said net DTH subscribers grew 193,000 in the final quarter to stand at 7.2 million at the year's end. Revenue rose 17 percent to 1.8 billion pounds. Profit rose to 130 million pounds from 12 million in the year-ago period. "These results show a business that continues to improve. We enter our second half with good momentum," said new CEO James Murdoch. News Corp. NWS, +1.90% is the largest minority holder of BSkyB. Agrichemicals group Syngenta '03 profits up 37% (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Swiss agrichemicals group Syngenta SYT, +3.29% on Wednesday said 2003 net income rose 37 percent to $363 million, on a 6 percent rise in revenues to $6.578 billion, or a 1 percent fall at constant exchange rates. Its top division, crop protection, posted a slight decline in revenues for the year at constant exchange rates, down 2 percent to $5.507 billion, but rose in the second half due to Latin American and NAFTA growth. EBITDA rose 6 percent to $1.219 billion for the year. For 2004, it said early signs of stabilization in the crop protection market point to a more favorable environment -- it sees high teens compound annual growth in earnings per share over the three years through 2006. Consumer electronics Thomson '03 net profits slump 93% (2:18 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- French consumer electronics group Thomson TMS, -25.00% (FR:018453)on Wednesday said 2003 net income dropped to 26 million euros from 373 million, with sales off 6.5 percent to 8.459 billion euros. In the fourth quarter, sales declined 6.7 percent, or rose 4.2 percent at constant currencies, to 2.693 billion euros, which reflects a growing sales in all its divisions, and particularly its Content & Networks division, the company said. Operating profits slumped 23.1 percent to 508 million euros, missing analyst targets of 517-540 million euros, according to an AFX poll. Going forward, the company sees 40 percent earnings before financial charges, taxes and amortization for 2004, assuming TCL-Thomson Electronics, its Chinese TV production joint venture, is up and running by mid-year and a break-even in Components. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Don’t ever do this with your credit card Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Aaon Corp. AAON, +1.04% saw its stock fall more than 7 percent to $17.95 after the Tulsa, Okla., maker of air conditioning and heating equipment posted a year-over-year increase in quarterly results but cautioned investors that it can't accurately predict its near-term future performance due to uncertainties in the economy and the potential impact of its new products. For the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, the company posted earnings of $3.7 million, or 30 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $3.1 million, or 23 cents per share. The mean estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 27 cents per share.
title: Aaon slides in wake of cautious outlook

content: BOSTON (CBS.MW) - Fidelity Investments's mutual fund managers were major buyers of large U.S. company stocks during the first quarter, documents filed with securities regulators Thursday show. The biggest U.S. mutual fund company was notably bullish on International Business Machines IBM, +0.60% and Amgen AMGN, +0.01% according to Fidelity Insight, a monthly newsletter that tracks the fund company. Fidelity Insight reviewed Fidelity's most recent 13-F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, focusing on the top 25 companies ranked by market size in the Standard & Poor's 500 index as of March 31. Shareholdings as of the end of the first quarter were matched against Fidelity's reported totals at Dec. 31. Fidelity added 14.7 million shares to its Amgen stake in the first quarter, boosting its ownership in the biotechnology giant by 65 percent over fourth-quarter 2002 holdings, Fidelity Insight said in a release. Additionally, Fidelity fund managers bought 13 million more shares of IBM in the quarter, an increase of 61 percent over their fourth-quarter holding in the computer-industry bellwether. Fidelity's plate also includes 51.7 million more shares of AOL Time Warner AOL a 24 percent increase since the end of last year, and 35 million new shares of General Electric Co. GE, -1.46% a 12 percent increase over the same period. The fund company also was a net buyer in the first quarter of Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% Pfizer PFE, +0.54% SBC Communications SBC, -0.65% Verizon Communications VZ, -0.37% and Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% among others. "They're definitely seeing some opportunities out there," John Bonnanzio, Fidelity Insight's editor, said of the fund family's trading activity. But he added that managers are being "very discriminating about what they're buying and selling." For example, although Fidelity was a buyer of SBC and Verizon, its managers sold 24 million shares of rival BellSouth Corp. BLS, +0.00% trimming the funds' stake in the telecom by 23 percent, Fidelity Insight's analysis shows. Although Fidelity portfolios still own 82.5 million BellSouth shares, "someone's gone negative on it," Bonnanzio said, adding that such selective activity in fact is a positive sign. "When you see Fidelity buying in one area of the market and selling another name, that suggests the analysts and managers are doing their homework," he explained. Fidelity also dumped 25.2 million shares of Altria Group MO, -0.21% in the first quarter, the filing indicated, reducing its stake in the tobacco and food giant by 23 percent to 82.9 million shares. A big footprint The latest 13-F shows that Fidelity's various investment divisions owned more than 7,000 stocks worldwide with a market value of roughly $375 billion as of March 31. The stakes encompassed a wide-range of sectors and companies from Aaon AAON, +1.04% a heating and cooling equipment maker, to Zymogenetics ZGEN a biotech firm. The 13-F, which all investment managers of a certain size are required to file with the SEC, is only a snapshot of holdings as of a specific date and may not reflect current positions. Fidelity leaves a huge footprint on any market, to be sure, and by default many of the stocks it buys will be among the top 25 companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index. But the trading comes at a time when weary investors haven't been giving Fidelity and most other fund companies as much money to invest in stocks. An estimated $2.6 billion in net new cash flowed into Fidelity funds in the first three months of this year, according to Financial Research Corp., an investment research firm. By comparison, Fidelity took in about $3.3 billion in March 2002 alone. Managers of several key Fidelity funds put new money to work in the first quarter, company data shows. Magellan FMAGX, +1.58% manager Bob Stansky modestly reduced his fund's cash position to 3.8 percent of assets from 4.4 percent. Contrafund FCNTX, +1.75% manager Will Danoff took cash down to 5.6 percent from 9.2 percent, while John Avery, manager of Fidelity Fund FFIDX, +1.44% reduced cash to 2.4 percent from 6.3 percent during the period. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000
title: SEC filing reveals fund giant is bullish on IBM, Amgen

content: Aaon Inc. AAON, +1.04% is saying that its board has approved the buyback of up to 10 percent, or 1,325,000 shares, of its common stock. The Tulsa, Okla., maker of commercial rooftop heating and air conditioning equipment plans to fund the repurchases using existing cash and future earnings. The stock closed Wednesday at $16.95, down 1.9 percent.
title: Aaon board oks buyback of up to 10% of stock

content: Stocks to watch Applied Micro Circuits, a communications chipmaker, on Tuesday reported a smaller net loss for the second quarter as stringent cost cuts offset a decline in revenue. The company AMCC had a net loss of $72.4 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with a loss of $95.9 million, or 32 cents, a year ago. Excluding special items and one-time charges, Applied Micro posted a pro forma loss of $11.8 million, or 4 cents a share -- beating the 5-cent loss forecast by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Last year, the company had a pro forma loss of $12.8 million, or 4 cents. Revenue came to $30.2 million -- nearly in line with expectations -- but down from $41.3 million last year. Shares of Applied Micro fell 2 cents to $3.65 in after hours trading. See full story. After the bell Tuesday, online ad and technology company DoubleClick DCLK reported a net loss of $62 million, or 46 cents per share on its third quarter. Excluding non-cash and non-recurring items, however, its "pro forma" net income came in at $6.6 million, or 5 cents per share. Total revenues at DoubleClick fell almost 20 percent on the period, to $74.6 million. Looking ahead, the company said it expects fourth-quarter revenues to come in a range of $62 million to $66 million, with pro forma per share figures from a loss of 1 cent to a profit of 1 cent. Shares of DoubleClick closed up just over 1 percent at $6.05 Tuesday. See full story. After the market closed Tuesday, motorcycle manufacturer Harley-Davidson Inc. reported higher third-quarter earnings that easily surpassed most Wall Street estimates. The company said it earned $165 million, or 54 cents a share, compared to $111.7 million, or 36 cents, in the year-ago period. On average, analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 47 cents in the latest period. Revenue climbed 32 percent to $1.14 billion. The company credited the increase to strong sales of commemorative products for its 100th anniversary, along with better-than-expected sales of accessories and MotorClothes apparel and collectibles. The shares HDI, -1.78% closed 85 cents higher at $53 ahead of the announcement. See full story. Intel INTC, +5.00% earned less than analysts expected during its third quarter, although revenue matched Wall Street's goal of $6.5 billion. The world's largest chipmaker said its fourth-quarter sales will be flat to up 6 percent sequentially. See full story. Internet Security Systems ISSX shares rose 3 percent following the close of trading Tuesday, after the security-software company beat profit expectations and boosted sales from the previous year. The company posted a profit of $6.34 million, or 13 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the company's net income was $5.85 million, or 12 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected ISS to earn 11 cents a share, on average. ISS shares rose to $16.70 after hours, up from $16.20 at the close of regular trading. See full story. Millennium Pharmaceuticals MLNM said Tuesday its third-quarter net loss widened to $98.9 million, or 35 cents per share, compared with $25.2 million, or 11 cents per share, in the 2001 third quarter. Excluding one-time charges, the biotech firm said its loss was $89.1 million, or 31 cents per share, wider than the 27 cent per-share loss analysts, on average, expected, according to Thomson First Call. Shares of Millennium slipped 23 cents to $9.77 in recent after-hours dealings. See full story. Motorola delivered a profit of 5 cents a share Tuesday, in line with expectations the telecommunications giant had twice reiterated. For the quarter, Motorola MSI, +1.29% pulled in revenues of $6.37 billion, led by strong sales of handsets. Strict controls on costs also contributed to the bottom-line results. Excluding all items, Motorola reported a profit of 6 cents a share, a penny ahead of expectations at First Call. Ahead of the news, Motorola shares traded in a range of $9.86 to $10.75, but closed at $10.10, the same spot they finished the prior day's session. See full story. Novellus Systems' NVLS CEO Richard Hill said the chip-equipment maker expects its fourth-quarter earnings to reach 11 cents a share, or nearly double the current 6-cents-a-share estimate of Wall Street analysts. Hill said there are "glimmers of hope" beginning to surface in the semiconductor equipment market that should boost Novellus' earnings. Hill also said revenue for the quarter will likely be $211 million. See full story. Advancers AaiPharma AAII rose almost 20 percent after the Wilmington, N.C., pharmaceutical development firm said that sales of its Darvon and Darvocet pain relief products totaled roughly $30.5 million, topping its expectations in the first six months since their acquisition. Based on this performance, the company raised its forecast for sales of Darvon and Darvocet in the first full year to between $50 million and $55 million. Aaon AAON, +1.04% added more than 6 percent after the company posted third-quarter net income of $4.2 million, or 30 cents per share, compared to $3.5 million, or 26 cents per share in the year-ago period. The latest number matched the forecast of 30 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Revenue increased to $41.7 million from $41.4 million. Alliance Gaming ALLY, +2.11% surged more than 14 percent. After Monday's closing bell, the Las Vegas-based firm reported first-quarter earnings of $6.3 million, or 13 cents a share, down from its year-ago profit of $7.4 million, or 16 cents a share, and a penny ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose to $146.7 million in the latest three months from $130 million in the same period a year earlier. AOL Time Warner AOL gained more than 7 percent after the company received an upgrade from SoundView Technology Group to an "outperform" rating from a "neutral" and its price target was lifted to $15 from $12. The firm said the release Tuesday of AOL's 8.0 version is "accompanied by a new mindset for the AOL unit: profitability and stability." See full story. Bank of America BAC, +2.04% surged more than 8 percent after the company posted third-quarter net income of $2.24 billion, or $1.45 per share, up from $841 million, 51 cents per share in the year-ago period. The latest number beat the forecast of $1.41 earnings in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Total revenue of $8.69 billion was about flat from the previous year. Analysts had targeted $8.79 billion. The third-quarter earnings included $1.25 billion in after-tax costs related to the exit of the company's auto leasing and sub-prime real estate lending businesses. Bank One ONE, -0.46% gained 7 percent after the company posted third-quarter net income of $823 million, or 70 cents a share, compared with $754 million, or 64 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The results were right in line with the Thomson First Call estimate. Revenue amounted to $4.2 billion in the third quarter vs. $4.0 billion in the year-ago quarter. The Chicago-based bank said it saw some growth in credit card, retail and investment management but acknowledged that the economic environment "continues to be uncertain and could constrain revenue growth." Black Box BBOX, -2.44% soared more than 15 percent after the company posted second-quarter earnings of $15 million, or 74 cents per share, compared to $17.1 million, or 83 cents per share, in the year-ago period. The latest number beat the forecast for EPS of 74 cents in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Revenues for the quarter were $163 million, down 17 percent from $197 million last year. Boston Beer Co. SAM, -0.11% surged more than 6 percent after the company posted third-quarter earnings of $362,000, or 2 cents a share, down from its year-ago profit of $2.8 million, or 17 cents a share, but ahead of the average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a loss of a penny per share. Sales leapt 15.2 percent to $56.6 million in the latest three months from $49.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Sales volume swelled 11.6 percent to 335,780 barrels in the quarter from 300,859 barrels in last year's equivalent quarter. The company said that increased revenue was offset by a higher cost of goods sold with changes in product mix and increases in material costs. Capitol Bancorp CBCL leapt more than 6 percent after the Lansing, Mich., firm reported third-quarter earnings of $4.4 million, or 40 cents a share, for the third quarter, 4 cents ahead of the average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue jumped more than 31 percent to $30.3 million in the latest three months from $23.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The company cited its "consistently improving operating leverage" for the strong performance. Charles Schwab SC.H, +0.00% advanced more than 10 percent after the company said its third-quarter operating income was $96 million, or 7 cents per share, compared to $81 million, or 6 cents per share last year. The latest EPS number matched the forecast of 7 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First call. Operating revenue was flat at $1 billion. Including all nonoperating items, the company reported a net loss of $4 million vs. net income of $13 million, or 1 cent per share last year. Clients opened 160,000 new accounts during the third quarter. The company ended the period with 8 million active accounts, up 3 percent. Citigroup C, -1.11% tacked on more than 12 percent after the company posted third quarter net earnings of 76 cents per share Tuesday, managing double-digit earnings growth despite an epic slowdown in capital markets activity in the last few years. The company reported core earnings of 74 cents per share, a penny ahead of the Wall Street consensus earnings estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63% surged more than 21 percent after the company reported third-quarter operating losses that were less than year-earlier levels and Wall Street expectations and announced plans to cut capital expenditures by $1.3 billion over the next two years through fleet reductions and the deferral of aircraft deliveries. Delta said it reached agreement with Boeing BA, +2.46% to "reschedule delivery" of all of its mainline aircraft in 2003 and 2004. See full story. Fannie Mae FNM, -11.67% rose nearly 7 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings that exceeded expectations and reiterated its forecast that full year earnings growth will be above the long-term trend. Net income for the quarter ending September was $1.63 billion, or $1.62 per share, up from $1.38 billion, or $1.33 a share in the year earlier period. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of $1.57 a share. Total taxable revenue for the period increased 15 percent to $2.99 billion. Looking ahead, the home mortgage financing company said making precise earnings forecasts for 2003 is "difficult," due to rapid portfolio growth at wider-than-normal spreads and "substantially elevated" liquidation levels. EDS EDS gained 10 percent after the company extended its strategic alliance with Dell Computer DELL The deal establishes EDS as provider of select Dell customer support services, and expands Dell's preferred provider status with EDS. Financial terms weren't disclosed. FSI International FSII rallied more than 21 percent. The Chaska, Minn., provider of microelectronics capital equipment is scheduled to report its fourth-quarter results after the closing bell. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for a loss of 30 cents a share in the period. Before the opening bell, the company named Edmund Tang president of its Asian business. Gannett Co. GCI, +0.50% rose almost 4 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $265.6 million, or 99 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $174.8 million, or 66 cents a share, and in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 4.2 percent to $1.58 billion in the latest three months from $1.52 billion in the same period a year earlier. The McLean, Va., media firm said that after-tax cash flow rose to $1.20 per share in the quarter from $1.05 per share in the same period a year earlier. Gannett attributed the growth to improvement in both its publishing and broadcasting operations, a decline in newsprint expense, a positive contribution from its Newsquest properties, and a decline in interest expense. See full story. General Motors GM, +2.45% jumped more than 10 percent after the company reported a third-quarter profit, excluding charges and gains, of $1.24 a share. GM had been expected to bring in a profit of 99 cents, according to the average poll of 16 analysts by Thomson First Call. On a net basis, GM lost more money than last year's third quarter, $804 million, or $1.42 a share, in the red this year vs. $368 million, or 41 cents a share, last year. Sales rose to $43.6 billion, up from $42.5 billion last year. The company also lifted its financial outlook for next year. See full story. Gentex GNTX, +1.86% surged almost 4 percent after the maker of automatic-dimming rearview mirrors reported third-quarter earnings that exceeded expectations. Net income for the quarter ending September was $21.4 million, or 28 cents a share, up from $14.9 million, or 20 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 27 cents a share, on average. Revenue rose 37 percent to $101.5 million. Handspring HAND added more than 5 percent after the company named Ed Colligan president, effective immediately. Colligan, a co-founder of the Mountain View, Calif., handheld computer firm, will continue to serve as chief operating officer. InforMax INMX leapt more than 135 percent after the company inked a definitive agreement to accept a $42 million cash buyout offer from Invitrogen IVGN The deal values InforMax shares at $1.36 each; well above their Monday close of 56 cents. The companies expect the cash tender offer to close by year-end. The news comes as InforMax, a Bethesda, Md., provider of life science informatics products and services, projected a loss before items of $5.2 million, or 20 cents a share, on revenue of $3.1 million in the third quarter. Invirtogen shares rose almost 1 percent. See full story. J.B. Hunt Transport Services JBHT, +1.94% leapt more than 16 percent after the Lowell, Ark., trucking firm reported third-quarter earnings of $16.8 million, or 42 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $4.5 million, or 12 cents a share, and 6 cents ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose to $583 million in the latest three months from $537 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the strong results to greater than expected realization of operating leverage in its truck segment. Lumenis Ltd. LUME added more than 18 percent after the company said that its Novus multi-color photocoagulation laser system has received marketing clearance from the Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of certain retinal diseases. The company also said that the transfer of its ophthalmic manufacturing operations to Salt Lake City is proceeding according to plan. Maytag shares MYG rose more than 16 percent Tuesday after the third largest appliance maker posted target-topping third-quarter earnings that grew by 48 percent from a year ago. Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% jumped more than 6 percent after Goldman Sachs said it expects the software giant to meet or exceed its estimates for earnings of 42 cents a share on revenue of $7.07 billion in the first quarter. Microsoft is slated to report on Thursday. "The quarter likely benefited from strong licensing activity in July before the July 31 deadline for Upgrade Advantage and Software Assurance," Goldman said. "PC demand was likely a bit below our expectations, but deferred revs were likely up much more significantly than we modeled earlier, providing an offsetting benefit to revenue." Mohawk Industries MHK, +1.45% gained more than 7 percent after the flooring company grew its third-quarter profits by 46 percent and beat expectations by a penny. Mueller Industries MLI, +1.24% advanced more than 5 percent after the company said third-quarter income from operations of $24.9 million, or 68 cents per share, compared to $18.2 million, or 49 cents per share in the year-ago period. Net sales fell to $238.5 million from $247.6 million. Net income was $46.6 million, or $1.27 per share, compared to $19 million, or 51 cents per share. Philip Morris MO, -0.21% rose more than 4 percent after analyst Judy Hong at Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock to "recommended for purchase" from "market outperformer," citing improved valuation following its recent share price decline, the likely dismantling of the Engle class action case in the next 6 to 9 months and the belief that concerns over U.S. cigarette fundamentals will abate over the next 6 to 12 months. Pilgrim's Pride CHX, -0.14% rallied more than 15 percent. The company commented late Monday on its voluntary recall of 27.4 million pounds of deli products, saying that it doesn't expect the move to have a material adverse effect on its financial condition. Pilgrim's Pride called the recall, "a precautionary step" following environmental sampling that suggested the continued presence of Listeria at its plant in Franconia, Pa., and said that it has adequate insurance to cover the recall. The shares plunged almost 25 percent in Monday's session in the wake of the news. This morning, Credit Suisse First Boston raised its rating on Pilgrim's Pride shares to "outperform" from "underperform" due to valuation. The firm set a 12-month price target of $12 on the stock. Playtex Products PYX, -5.19% rose more than 14 percent after Banc of America raised its rating on shares of the Westport, Conn., consumer products firm to "buy," citing valuation. The firm called the stock's level "too difficult to ignore" and set a price target of $11. Playtex shares plumbed a 52-week low of $6.95 on Oct. 10. State Street STT, +1.91% leapt more than 5 percent after the company said third-quarter earnings rose 6 percent to 56 cents a share, including 2 cents a share in goodwill expenses vs. 53 cents in the year-ago period. Revenue (on a tax-equivalent basis) was $972 million in the quarter, down 1 percent. Total assets under custody were $5.7 trillion vs. $5.8 trillion a year ago. Tractor Supply TSCO, +5.03% jumped more than 18 percent after the Nashville, Tenn., farm and ranch products retailer reported third-quarter earnings of $7.8 million, or 39 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $2.4 million, or 13 cents a share, and well ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 27 cents a share. Sales jumped 48.5 percent to $296.2 million in the latest three months from $199.4 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales rose 7.7 percent in the period. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of $34 million to $34.4 million, or $1.71 to $1.73 per share, on sales of between $1.19 billion and $1.20 billion in the full year. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of $1.57 per share. Earlier in the session, the stock hit a 52-week high of $37.50. Unisys UIS, +2.38% soared more than 32 percent after the company surpassed targets in its third quarter due to tighter cost controls and strength in its services and technology business. Vivendi Universal V, +2.25% rose more than 8 percent after a French newspaper reported that mobile operator Vodafone VOD, +0.54% might make a bid for the cash-strapped media group in order to get its hands on its telecommunications interests. For its part, Vivendi said its bankers have given commitments to extend a $1.62 billion credit line. Wal-Mart WMT, +1.37% surged 4 percent after the Bentonville, Ark., retailing giant said it would begin testing a home-delivery DVD rental service in October at a monthly subscription rate of $18.86 and with a selection of over 12,000 titles. After fine-tuning the service, based on initial customer feedback, Wal-Mart plans a nationwide rollout next year. See full story. Wells Fargo WFC, +1.81% gained more than 5 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $1.44 billion, or 84 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $1.31 billion, or 75 cents a share, and in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The San Francisco-based financial services firm attributed the strong performance to continued broad-based double-digit revenue growth, improved credit quality and well-controlled expenses. Revenue totaled $6.04 billion in the latest three months, a jump of 10 percent from $5.48 billion in the same period a year ago. Decliners Analysts International ANLY fell more than 14 percent. Earlier in the session, the stock plumbed a 52-week low of $1.10 per share. The Minneapolis information technology services firm has issued a press release saying that it knows of no reason for the weakness in its share price over the past four to five trading days. "While there continue to be general concerns about the state of the industry and the market for IT services, the current selling pressure and price of the stock do not reflect our view of the company's value or its prospects," said Michael LaVelle, the company's president and CEO, in a press release. The shares are down for six straight sessions. On Oct. 7, the stock closed at $2.74. Beckman Coulter BEC, -2.19% slumped more than 23 percent after the company lowered its earnings outlook to reflect modest revenue growth due to the continued decline in pharmaceutical and biotechnology spending. The Fullerton, Calif., provider of laboratory products now sees an earnings decline of 2 to 3 percent for the third quarter, well below its previous outlook for growth of 19 to 22 percent from its year-ago profit of 52 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for a profit of 60 cents a share in the period. Revenue for the third quarter is projected at $501 million, a 5 percent jump from its total in the same period a year earlier, but less than its projection for growth of about 10 percent. Integrated Defense Technologies IDE, +1.67% plunged more than 7 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter EPS of 21- to 22 cents per share, below the current forecast of 31 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. It sees EPS of 31- to 33 cents per share, below the target of 41 cents per share, for the fourth quarter. The company cited the competitive loss of certain programs and delays in other awards. Mirant MIR, -20.00% dropped almost 10 percent after Fitch Ratings lowered its rating on the company's senior notes and convertible securities to "BB" -- considered "junk" status -- from "BBB-," as the problems weighing on all the gas and power wholesale merchants hurt the company's access to the capital and credit markets. Specifically, Mirant has been negatively affected by reduced trading volumes, lower market prices, reduced profitability of power production, regulatory investigations and the demise of its former auditor. Fitch said the outlook for the rating remains "negative." Separately, Mirant said its would file its fiscal second quarter Form 10-Q with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on about Nov. 1, later than previous estimates of a "mid-October" filing. Pentair PNR, +0.35% tumbled more than 8 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings that matched expectations but lowered its outlook for the year due to "more aggressive" pricing pressures, slower productivity improvements in its water technologies segment and promotional activities in its tools business. Net income for the quarter ending September was $37.3 million, or 75 cents a share, up from 50 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue for the quarter declined 1.1 percent from last year to $629.3 million. For the year, the company cut its earnings forecast to $2.60 to $2.65 a share from $2.80 to $2.90 a share. Quaker Fabric QFAB dropped more than 5 percent after the Fall River, Mass., maker of furniture upholstery fabrics reported third-quarter earnings of $1.5 million, or 9 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $331,000, or 2 cents a share, but 4 cents below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose to $81 million in the latest three months from $76.4 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the shortfall to the absence of a seasonal rebound in its business in August. Looking ahead, Quaker Fabric said that its outlook for the fourth quarter is largely dependent on the state of the general economy, and that it plans to reduce capital spending in the fourth quarter by $5 million. Troy Group TROY slumped more than 22 percent after the Santa Ana, Calif., check printing and payment technology firm delayed the filing of its form 10-Q with the Securities and Exchange Commission, saying that it has discovered "certain physical inventory shortfalls." The company said that it discovered the discrepancies during the relocation of its headquarters. Troy puts the amount in question at $1.5 million. The company also forecast a loss of $1.1 million, or 10 cents a share, for the first nine months of 2002, including a charge of $2.1 million to reflect the inventory adjustments and severance costs related to plant closings and consolidation efforts. WCI Communities WCI, -2.49% plummeted more than 25 percent after the company warned that third-quarter and full-year earnings would fall short of expectations, due to the likely default of five purchase contracts and the potential of up to 48 purchasers to exercise their right to cancel their contracts. The homebuilder now expects to earn 20 to 24 cents a share in the quarter ending September and $2.28 to $2.37 a share for the year, versus prior forecasts of 32 to 37 cents a share and $2.45 to $2.58 a share, respectively. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch: Intel, Motorola, Millennium Pharma

content: Stocks to Watch AOL Time Warner AOL said late Tuesday it will cut its work force by about 1,700 positions, including 500 from its Sun-Netscape alliance, as part of a restructuring plan. As a result, AOL Time Warner expects to take a charge of between $100 million and $125 million in the third quarter of this year. Shares fell 0.8 percent to $39.90 by the end of the regular session and then another 50 cents after hours. See full story. The Finova Group FNV, +2.06% said it was emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after if received a $5.6 billion loan from Berkadia LLC, a joint entity of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and Leucadia National Corp. As part of Finova's reorganization plan, Berkadia has received a 50 percent ownership stake. Shares closed up 4 cents, or 1.1 percent, at $3.64. Software maker Intuit INTU, +1.42% reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $61.3 million, or 29 cents a share. During the same quarter last year, net income was $17.1 million, or 8 cents a share. But revenue for the quarter ended July 31 was $191.2 million compared with $162.3 million during the same quarter last year. Ahead of the report, shares ended down $1.75, or 5.6 percent, at $29.45. In after hours action, shares gained back another $2.48. See full story. Saks SKS, +0.75% reported a second-quarter loss of 30 cents a share late Tuesday. Wall Street had expected a 31-cent loss. The parent of the luxury chain of stores bearing its name -- as well as Carson Pirie Scott, Proffitt's, McRae's and Younkers, among others -- said it "remains cautious" on its outlook for the rest of the year. Shares fell 19 cents to $10.51 in the regular session. See full story. General Motors GM, +2.45% the world's No. 1 automaker, said late Tuesday that it's going to earn 83 cents a share during the third quarter, as the company had said it would. Shares fell 30 cents to $55.70 in the regular session, then gained $1.05 after hours. See full story. Be Free BFRE, +0.00% will cut 55 employees, or 25 percent of its work force, to 175, the company reported. Also, the online marketer said its third and fourth quarter revenues and losses will be consistent with previous targets provided on July 25. Thomas Gerace, co-founder and chief marketing officer, will no longer be the top marketer, but will advise the company on strategic initiatives. "We believe that our more efficient business model and strong balance sheet will allow Be Free to achieve its second quarter 2002 goals of profitability before non-cash charges, and a cash reserve of more than $100 million," said CEO and Chairman Gordon B. Hoffstein. Shares closed down 10 cents at $1.75. Sycamore Networks SCMR which makes products that help speed up data transmission on fiber-optic networks, reported a fourth-quarter loss of $29 million, or 12 cents a share, vs. a profit of $11.5 million, or 4 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call expected Sycamore to lose, on average, 12 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Shares of Sycamore closed at a new 52-week low of $5 ahead of the announcement. See full story. After the market closed, Hutchinson Technology HTCH said it plans to cut 600 jobs and reaffirmed its previously guidance. The company said it expects fourth-quarter results to include a pre-tax charge of $4.5 million to $5.5 million, or 15 cents to 20 cents a share, related to severance costs. Excluding charges, the company expects a loss between 35 cents and 50 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call currently expect a loss of 38 cents a share. The company said revenue will come in between $90 million and $105 million. Analysts currently expect revenue of about $96 million. Shares closed down 39 cents at $19.16. Shares fell another 28 cents after hours. After the market closed, Semtech SMTC, +1.17% posted second-quarter pro forma earnings of $6.1 million, or 8 cents a share, on sales of $40.5 million. Analysts polled by First Call anticipated a profit of 7 cents, on revenue of about $39 million. In the year-ago period, the company earned $13.7 million, or 18 cents a share, on revenue of $60.6 million. The company said it did see an improvement in order rates during the latter half of the second quarter. The company expects sequential growth in the range of 3 to 5 percent for third-quarter sales, which equates to between $41.7 million and $42.6 million. It said earnings should be about 8 cents to 9 cents a share. Analysts currently expect a profit of 8 cents a share and revenue of about $41 million. Shares closed down $2.36 to $30.20, but added $1.56 after hours. Advancers AAON AAON, +1.04% added more than 1 percent after the Tulsa, Okla., maker of air conditioning and heating equipment declared a three-for-two split of its common stock. The split will be paid September 28 to shareholders of record on September 10. Calpine C.PN, +0.59% surged 5.8 percent to $29.90 after the company held a conference call Monday and reiterated its goal of reaching 70,000 megawatts of generating capacity by the end of 2005. Ronald Barone, an analyst with UBS Warburg, noted that, while Calpine did reiterate the goal, it also indicated for the first time that it was not 'locked into' the target. "Specifically, pursuit of this target will depend in large part on management's continued positive view of the power market, and to a lesser extent, financing opportunities," Barone said in a research note to clients. He also disclosed that Calpine has moved back plans for an equity offering to the end of the first quarter of 2002 from the fourth quarter due to stronger than expected cash flow, and that the company still believes the U.S. is experiencing a supply/demand imbalance. Genesis Bioventures GBI, -2.65% rose 25 cents, or 9.6 percent, to $2.85 after the New York firm agreed to acquire Biotherapies' interest in Biomedical Diagnostics, a joint venture between the two companies. The venture focuses on research, development and commercialization of products used for predictive and diagnostic medicine. Financial terms of the combined cash and stock deal weren't disclosed. Guidant GDT surged $3.40, or 10.8 percent, to $35. Merrill Lynch raised its intermediate-term rating on the stock to "accumulate" from "neutral" after the company acquired exclusive rights to distribute Cook's paciltaxcel coated stents. The deal may further "slow share inroads" by Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% the market leader in coated stents. Intrado TRDO zoomed $4.05, or 19.6 percent, to $24.75 after the Boulder, Colo., telecommunications technology firm announced that its proposal to create a centralized database of up to 1.5 billion telephone numbers has been accepted by the Ordering and Billing Forum Task Force of the Alliance for the Telecommunications Industry Solutions. The selection of Intrado for this task will not be deemed final, however, until the proposed solution is ratified by a vote of the funding companies of the Ordering and Billing Forum. The vote is expected in October Metro Information Services MISI skyrocketed 109.5 percent to $7.75 after the Virginia Beach, Va., information technology consulting and software design firm agreed to be acquired by Keane KEA for roughly $135 million in stock. The deal calls for Keane to swap 0.48 common shares for each Metro share. Keane will also assume debt of $68 million from Metro. Keane shares lost more than 8 percent to $17.01 in afternoon action. OpenTV OPTV rose 92 cents, or 12 percent, to $8.57 after the Mountain View, Calif., interactive television technology firm said its iTV software has been ported and certified to run on IBM's IBM, +0.60% PowerPC-based set-top box chips. Sonic Innovations SNCI, +0.13% added 64 cents, or 18.9 percent, to $4.03 after the Salt Lake City producer of digital hearing aids said that an independent clinical study found its Natura 2 SE products "help impaired people to understand speech better in noisy environments." The study was conducted at Washington University, School of Medicine in St. Louis. Spectra-Physics SPLI soared $7.16, or 52.3 percent, to $20.85 after Thermo Electron TMO, +0.26% said it plans to take its 80-percent owned unit private at $20 per share. Thermo Electron expects to begin a cash tender offer for the Spectra-Physics' shares it doesn't already own by the end of September. Decliners Adelphia Business Solutions ABIZ lost 72 cents, or 31.3 percent, to close at $1.58. On Monday, Moody's Investors Service changed the outlook for the debt and preferred stock ratings of Adelphia Communications Corp. ADLAC and all of its units, which include majority-owned Adelphia Business, to negative. The service noted that Adelphia Business has a funding shortfall of roughly $1 billion that will need to resolved "one way or another." American Eagle Outfitters AEOS dropped $9.06, or 28.1 percent, to $23.21 after the company reported second-quarter net income of $15.3 million, or 21 cents per share, up from a year-ago profit of $2.8 million, or 4 cents per share, and in line with Wall Street expectations. However, for the third quarter, the Warrendale, Pa., casual apparel retailer expects earnings growth of 10 to 15 percent, yielding per-share profits of 45 to 47 cents a share, and flat same-store sales. This outlook is 2 cents below the average view of analysts polled by Thomson Financial. See full story. Candela CLZR dove $1.28, or 18.3 percent, to $5.70 after the Waltham, Mass., clinical laser technology firm reported a fourth-quarter loss of $43,000, or break even on a per-share basis, down from a year-ago profit of $4.9 million, or 40 cents a share. The latest quarter includes charges of $1.1 million for continuing lease liabilities from its discontinued Scottsdale spa operations and $640,000 for asset impairments in its Boston spa. Revenue dropped in the period to $18.2 million from $22.4 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said it remains confident that it can return to a "sustainable growth path" but it believes that it may take "2 or 3 quarters before we can acheive our goal." Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call were looking for a profit of 18 cents a share in June quarter. C&D Technologies CHP, -16.67% sank $6.71, or 24.8 percent, to $20.30 after the Blue Bell, Pa., provider of electrical power storage and conversion products reported a second-quarter earnings of $13.1 million, or 49 cents a share, down slightly from its year-ago profit of $13.4 million, or 49 cents a share, and 4 cents below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales slid 18 percent in the latest three months to $125.5 million. The company cited slowing demand in its key markets for the sales decline, and warned that it expects earnings of 30 cents a share in the third quarter. This is well below Wall Street's current consensus estimate of 55 cents a share for the period. Colorado Medtech CMED, +7.93% tumbled $1.20, or 30 percent, to $2.80 after the Boulder, Colo., provider of outsourced medical technology services reported a fourth-quarter loss before items of $804,000, or 6 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $363,000, or 3 cents a share, but in line with Wall Street expectations. Including a gain of $921,000 from the sale of its catheter unit, and a charge of $3.1 million from an inventory write-down, Colorado Medtech lost $1.7 million, or 13 cents a share, in the quarter. Sales rose in the latest three months to $20.5 million from $17 million in the same period a year earlier. The company noted that issues related to the warning letter it has received from the Food and Drug Administration remain unresolved. "We believe that our quality systems are greatly improved," said Stephen Onody, the company's chairman and CEO, in a press release. "We obtained the independent audit required by the FDA, and are waiting for the FDA to complete its review." Engineered Support Systems EASI fell $6.06, or 15.5 percent, to $33.05 after the St. Louis maker of electronics and manufacturing support equipment reported third-quarter earnings of $4.8 million, or 46 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $3.8 million, or 42 cents a share, and in line with Wall Street expectations. Revenue rose 6 percent in the latest three months to $99.2 million from $93.3 million in the same period a year earlier. Backlog as of July 31 reached 1.01 billion, a jump of 11 percent from its Oct. 31, 2000 total. However, for the fourth quarter, the company said that it expects earnings of 47 cents a share on revenue of $100 million to $105 million, a penny below the current consensus profit estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Hain Celestial HAIN, +0.69% sank more than 9 percent after the company cut its financial targets for the fourth quarter. HNC Software HNCS dropped $2.71, or 11.2 percent, to $21.53 after the company sold $125 million in 5.25 percent convertible subordinated notes due Sept. 1, 2008. Initial purchasers received an option from the San Diego, Calif., software firm to procure an additional $25 million worth of the notes, which are convertible into shares of the company's common stock at a conversion price of $28.80 per share. Polymedica PLMD shares plunged more than 13 percent before the stock was halted in afternoon action. The Woburn, Mass., medical products firm was sold off in early August when reports surfaced, and were eventually confirmed by the company, that it was the subject of a criminal investigation by the U.S. Attorney's office. The investigation is believed to be related to Liberty Medical Supply, which Polymedica acquired in 1996. Sorrento Networks FIBR, -0.08% tripped $2.42, or 13.8 percent, to $15.18 after the San Diego, Calif., provider of optical networking equipment said it expects second-quarter revenue of roughly $8 million. This performance represents a 50 percent increase from the same period a year earlier but a 45 percent drop on a sequential basis. Sorrento also said it shipped orders worth roughly $2.4 million that will become eligible for revenue recognition in future periods. The company plans to release its second-quarter results on Sept. 5. Staples SPLS fell 93 cents, or 5.7 percent, $15.29 after the company said it expects earnings for the year of 65 to 70 cents a share, in line with expectations for an average estimate of Thomson Financial/First Call for a profit of 67 cents. The retailer also posted second-quarter earnings of $40.4 million, or 9 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $42.6 million of 10 cents a share, but in line with Wall Street expectations. Sales in the latest three months rose 5 percent to $2.3 billion. Same-store sales were flat in the quarter. Talbots TLB, -5.71% lost $3.87, or 9.5 percent, $36.68 after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $17.8 million, or 28 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $14.6 million, or 23 cents a share, and a penny ahead of Wall Street expectations. Total company sales rose 6 percent in the latest three months to $384.3 million from $361.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The Hingham, Mass., women's apparel retailer and cataloger said same-store sales at its retail stores rose 1.8 percent in the quarter, and catalog sales totaled $49.8 million in the period. TriQuint Semiconductor TQNT dropped $2.82, or 12.7 percent, to $19.40-. The Hillsboro, Ore., supplier of gallium arsenide integrated circuits plans to hold a conference call after the closing bell to discuss a number of topics, including its outlook for 2001. Ahead of the call, Merrill Lynch said it believes TriQuint "could lower sequential revenue and EPS expectations for its 3Q01 due to continued shortfalls in its broadband business." The firm maintained its "accumulate/buy" rating on Triquint, citing a "relatively attractive valuation and continued improvement in its wireless business." More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you 2 sexy ways to get paid to save BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Calpine, Intrado, Polymedica, and more

content: Downgrades Company Broker New Old Comments Unit Corp. UNT, +21.08% First Union Securities Buy Strong Buy After initial price target passed; raises target to $13 from $9.50 MP3.com mppp Robertson Stephens Long-Term Attractive Buy In light of uncertainty co. facing short-term, possibility of damages Wild Oats Markets oats Dain Rauscher Neutral Buy On lower sales and expected margin pressure Cambridge Tech. Ptners.
